title: Effects of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors on sleep disturbances in Parkinson's disease: A network meta-analysis.
abstract: This network meta-analysis aimed to evaluate the effects of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors on sleep disturbances in Parkinson's disease (PD), a common non-motor symptom that significantly impacts quality of life. Seven studies were included in the analysis, focusing on subjective sleep quality, daytime sleepiness, and objective polysomnography (PSG) parameters. While no significant differences were observed among MAO-B and COMT inhibitors in improving subjective sleep quality or daytime sleepiness, safinamide demonstrated notable effects on PSG data. Specifically, safinamide significantly increased REM sleep duration and decreased wake time after sleep onset compared to rasagiline and placebo. aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Sleep disturbances are common and debilitating non-motor symptoms (NMS) in Parkinson's disease (PD), profoundly affecting quality of life. Despite emerging evidence suggesting that monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) inhibitors may alleviate NMS, their specific effects on sleep remain unclear. This network meta-analysis (NMA) aimed to compare the efficacy of these inhibitors on sleep problems in PD.

Following a systematic search of PubMed, Cochrane, and EMBASE, studies comparing MAO-B or COMT inhibitors and assessing sleep outcomes in PD were identified. An NMA was conducted using data from the seven studies that met our inclusion criteria. Outcomes included subjective sleep quality, daytime sleepiness, and objective polysomnography (PSG) parameters.

No statistically significant differences were found among MAO-B and COMT inhibitors in improving subjective sleep quality or daytime sleepiness. However, in analyses of objective PSG data, safinamide was found to significantly increase REM sleep duration (mean difference, 5.70 [95% CI, 2.26, 9.14]) and decrease wake time after sleep onset (mean difference, -10.20 [-19.38, -1.02]) compared to rasagiline and placebo.

These findings suggest that safinamide may offer additional value for managing sleep disruptions beyond its known motor benefits in patients with PD. Given the limited number and small scale of available trials, the overall evidence should be interpreted cautiously. Nonetheless, this analysis highlights the need for further high-quality trials focused on sleep outcomes to guide personalized use of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors for sleep disturbances in PD.
aiInferenceData.Title: Effects of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors on sleep disturbances in Parkinson's disease: A network meta-analysis.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Lee SM, Shim SR, Kwon KY, Rhee TG, Jung YJ. Effects of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors on sleep disturbances in Parkinson's disease: A network meta-analysis. J Mov Disord. 2025;

In this study, Rasagiline was analyzed in the context of its effects on sleep disturbances in PD patients, which aligns with its conventional use. There is no indication of off-label use or non-conventional administration.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link Rasagiline to any adverse effects or negative outcomes.

title: Interaction between rasagiline and Pueraria radix in in vitro models of parkinson's disease.
abstract: This study investigates the pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic interactions between Rasagiline (RASA), a monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor, and Pueraria root (PR), a traditional East Asian medicine, in in vitro models of Parkinson's disease (PD). The research focuses on the synergistic effects of RASA and PR on MAO-B inhibition and neuroprotection against 6-OHDA-induced toxicity in PC12 cells. The study revealed that co-administration of RASA and PR at specific ratios significantly enhanced MAO-B inhibition and increased cell survival rates compared to individual treatments. The combination index analysis confirmed strong synergistic effects, suggesting that lower doses of each compound could achieve therapeutic effects while reducing side effects. Additionally, the investigation of CYP450 metabolism demonstrated minimal interference between RASA and PR, indicating favorable metabolic compatibility. The findings establish a scientific foundation for integrating traditional herbal medicine with conventional pharmaceuticals in PD management, potentially improving therapeutic outcomes and reducing conventional drug dosages. However, the study is limited to in vitro models, and further validation in primary dopaminergic neuron cultures, in vivo PD models, and clinical trials is necessary to confirm the translational relevance of the observed synergistic interactions.

aiInferenceData.Author_perspective: The article comments positively on the synergistic effects of Rasagiline and Pueraria root, highlighting their enhanced therapeutic potential and favorable metabolic compatibility in in vitro models of Parkinson's disease.
aiInferenceData.Abstract:
The management of Parkinson's disease (PD) remains challenging owing to the limitations of current therapies. Although rasagiline (RASA), a monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor, offers advantages over levodopa, its efficacy as a monotherapy is moderate. Pueraria root (PR), a traditional East Asian medicine, has demonstrated neuroprotective potential against several neurodegenerative conditions. This study investigated the pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic interactions between RASA and PR to evaluate their potential as a combination therapy for PD.

We examined synergistic effects on MAO-B inhibition by performing MAO-B enzyme reaction assay. We measured the cell viability for evaluating the neuroprotective effects of their co-administration against 6-OHDA-induced toxicity in PC12 cells. For investigating the interaction of drug metabolism, CYP450 expressions were measured in hepatocytes using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction.

Concentration-dependent studies revealed a significant synergistic inhibition of MAO-B activity when RASA and PR were co-administered at specific ratios, as confirmed by combination index analysis. Although neither of the two drugs alone provided significant neuroprotection at concentrations effective for MAO-B inhibition, their co-administration significantly increased the survival of in 6-OHDA-treated cells. Importantly, investigation of CYP450 metabolism demonstrated minimal interference between these compounds, with no significant alterations in the expression patterns of relevant CYP isoforms during co-administration.

These findings suggest that the RASA - PR combination offers enhanced therapeutic potential through synergistic effects, while maintaining favourable metabolic compatibility. This study establishes a scientific foundation for integrating traditional herbal medicine with conventional pharmaceuticals in PD management, potentially allowing for reduced conventional drug dosages while improving therapeutic outcomes.
aiInferenceData.Title: Interaction between rasagiline and Pueraria radix in in vitro models of parkinson's disease.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Huh E, Kim JH, Lee S, Oh MS. Interaction between rasagiline and Pueraria radix in in vitro models of parkinson's disease. BMC Complement Med Ther. 2025;25(1):409
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: The test subjects involved in this study include PC12 cells, which are derived from rat adrenal pheochromocytoma and are used as a model for neuronal studies. Additionally, liver tissues from Sprague-Dawley rats were utilized to measure MAO-B activity and investigate CYP450 enzyme expression.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, Rasagiline (RASA), demonstrated significant effects in this study. It exhibited MAO-B inhibitory activity and, when co-administered with Pueraria radix (PR), showed synergistic effects on MAO-B inhibition and enhanced neuroprotection against 6-OHDA-induced toxicity in PC12 cells. The combination therapy significantly increased cell survival rates compared to individual treatments.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Rasagiline is conventionally used as a monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor for the treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD). It is administered orally to patients with mild symptoms to maintain brain dopamine levels and provide neuroprotective effects. In this study, Rasagiline was administered in vitro to PC12 cells and rat liver tissues to evaluate its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic interactions with Pueraria radix. The study aimed to explore its potential as part of a combination therapy for PD.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study mentions Rasagiline's potential side effects and food interactions, necessitating dietary guidance during treatment. Additionally, the investigation into CYP450 enzyme expression highlights the importance of understanding metabolic interactions to ensure safety in combination therapies.

title: Add-on therapies to levodopa improve pain modulation in Parkinson's disease with motor fluctuations: A prospective cohort study.
abstract: This prospective cohort study aimed to evaluate the effect of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors, including rasagiline, as add-on therapies to levodopa on pain thresholds in people with Parkinson's disease (pwPD) experiencing motor fluctuations. Forty pwPD were enrolled, and their pain thresholds were assessed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. Normative data from 11 healthy subjects were used for comparison. The study revealed that pwPD had altered pain processing, with higher tactile thresholds and lower pain and pain tolerance thresholds compared to controls. Rasagiline and safinamide significantly improved pain thresholds and tolerance at 6 months, outperforming opicapone. Pain was more frequent in women and associated with anxiety, poor sleep, and motor complications. Regression analyses identified cognitive status, sex, disease duration, age, anxiety levels, and treatment with MAO-B inhibitors as key modulators of pain processing. The study concluded that MAO-B inhibitors, particularly safinamide and rasagiline, restore pain thresholds and improve QOL, supporting their role in managing pain in PD.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Pain is a common and often underestimated non-motor symptom in Parkinson's disease (PD), affecting quality of life (QOL) and frequently associated with motor fluctuations. Although the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying pain in PD remain unclear, most hypothesize the involvement of dopaminergic and non-dopaminergic pathways.

To evaluate the effect of MAO-B and COMT inhibitors, used as add-on therapies to levodopa, on pain thresholds in people with PD (pwPD) with motor fluctuations, either with or without pain.

This prospective cohort study enrolled 40 pwPD with motor fluctuations who were started on selegiline, rasagiline, safinamide, or opicapone. Pain thresholds (tactile, pain, and tolerance) were assessed using electrical stimulation at baseline and after 3 and 6 months. Normative data were collected from 11 healthy subjects. Outcome measures in pwPD targeted motor impairment (UPDRS), pain perception (King's PD Pain Scale), mood, fatigue, sleep, and QOL.

PwPD showed higher tactile thresholds and lower pain and pain tolerance thresholds than controls. At 6 months, both rasagiline and safinamide significantly improved pain thresholds and tolerance compared to opicapone. Experiencing pain was more frequent in women and was associated with anxiety, poor sleep, and motor complications. Regression analyses revealed that cognitive status, sex, disease duration, age, anxiety levels and treatment with MAO-B inhibitors were key modulators of pain processing.

Pain processing is altered in pwPD, independently of subjective pain complaints. MAO-B inhibitors, particularly safinamide and rasagiline, appear to restore pain thresholds and improve QOL, supporting their role in managing pain in PD.

title: Antipsychotic Polypharmacy for Treatment Resistant Schizoaffective Disorder: A Case Report.
abstract: This case report discusses a male patient in his early 20s with treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder and cannabis use disorder. Despite multiple trials of antipsychotics, including lithium, risperidone, olanzapine, and divalproex, the patient experienced persistent psychotic symptoms such as hyper-religiosity, hallucinations, mood lability, agitation, and aggression. Clozapine was considered but not administered due to concerns about monitoring requirements. The patient was treated with paliperidone LAI, divalproex, and haloperidol, which led to significant improvement in his symptoms. Haloperidol was introduced at a low dose and titrated to 2 mg BID, resulting in rapid symptom stabilization and reduced intensity of perceptual disturbances. The patient was discharged with a stable medication regimen, including paliperidone LAI 234 mg every four weeks, divalproex 750 mg BID, and haloperidol 2 mg BID. He did not experience any adverse effects or extrapyramidal symptoms during hospitalization. The case highlights the potential benefits of antipsychotic polypharmacy in managing treatment-resistant psychosis and emphasizes the importance of individualized treatment plans. While clozapine is often preferred for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, this case demonstrates the utility of alternative antipsychotic combinations in achieving symptom resolution. The study also discusses the challenges and limitations of antipsychotic polypharmacy, including the need for further research on safety and efficacy.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: This case presents a male in his early 20s with schizoaffective disorder and cannabis use disorder presenting with treatment resistance demonstrated by inadequate control of psychotic symptoms despite multiple trials of antipsychotics. The patient was experiencing positive symptoms, including hyper-religiosity, hallucinations, mood lability, agitation, and aggression. The patient and next of kin were unable to provide consent for clozapine due to concerns for monitoring requirements. The patient continued paliperidone long-acting injectable (LAI) 234 milligrams (mg) every four weeks and divalproex 750 mg twice per day (BID) and was started on haloperidol with titration to 2 mg BID. Following the addition of a second antipsychotic agent, the patient exhibited marked improvement with reduced intensity of perceptual disturbances. This case underscores the potential benefits and challenges of antipsychotic polypharmacy in addressing residual psychosis and improving functional outcomes. We also provide an overview of available evidence for and against antipsychotic polypharmacy, defined as two or more antipsychotic medications used in a patient concurrently, as well as alternative non-antipsychotic agents for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
aiInferenceData.Title: Antipsychotic Polypharmacy for Treatment Resistant Schizoaffective Disorder: A Case Report.

The patient was treated with other antipsychotics and anticonvulsants instead. Therefore, Clozapine was not used in a non-conventional or off-label manner in this study.
aiInferenceData.Justification: Clozapine was not administered in this study, and no adverse effects or negative outcomes related to its use were reported.

drugEffect: Drug effect: The patient exhibited marked improvement in psychotic and mood symptoms, with resolution of distressing symptoms and return to premorbid functioning. He expressed future-oriented thinking and mood stability.
summary: This case report discusses a male patient in his early 20s with treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder and cannabis use disorder. Despite multiple trials of antipsychotics, including lithium, risperidone, olanzapine, and divalproex, the patient experienced persistent psychotic symptoms such as hyper-religiosity, hallucinations, mood lability, agitation, and aggression. Clozapine was considered but not administered due to concerns about monitoring requirements. The patient was treated with paliperidone LAI, divalproex, and haloperidol, which led to significant improvement in his symptoms. Haloperidol was introduced at a low dose and titrated to 2 mg BID, resulting in rapid symptom stabilization and reduced intensity of perceptual disturbances. The patient was discharged with a stable medication regimen, including paliperidone LAI 234 mg every four weeks, divalproex 750 mg BID, and haloperidol 2 mg BID. He did not experience any adverse effects or extrapyramidal symptoms during hospitalization. The case highlights the potential benefits of antipsychotic polypharmacy in managing treatment-resistant psychosis and emphasizes the importance of individualized treatment plans. While clozapine is often preferred for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, this case demonstrates the utility of alternative antipsychotic combinations in achieving symptom resolution. The study also discusses the challenges and limitations of antipsychotic polypharmacy, including the need for further research on safety and efficacy.
authorPerspective: The article comments positively on the effect of haloperidol in combination with paliperidone LAI and divalproex, noting marked improvement in the patient's psychotic and mood symptoms. It emphasizes the importance of individualized treatment plans and highlights the potential benefits of antipsychotic polypharmacy for treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder.
vancouverCitation: Moriarty SE, Parhami P, Parikh J, Galicki L. Antipsychotic Polypharmacy for Treatment Resistant Schizoaffective Disorder: A Case Report. Cureus. 2025;17(3):e80204
approvedIndication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and psychotic disorders during Parkinson's disease when standard treatments fail. It is administered orally and requires monitoring due to potential severe side effects. In this study, Clozapine was not administered to the patient due to concerns about monitoring requirements. The patient was treated with other antipsychotics and anticonvulsants instead. Therefore, Clozapine was not used in a non-conventional or off-label manner in this study.
justification: Clozapine was not administered in this study, and no adverse effects or negative outcomes related to its use were reported.

title: Acute exposure to clozapine and sodium valproate impairs oxidative phosphorylation in human cardiac mitochondria.
abstract: This study investigated the acute effects of Clozapine (CLZ) and Sodium Valproate (VPA) on human cardiac mitochondria, focusing on their role in cardiotoxicity. Tissue samples from 24 consenting patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting were used to assess mitochondrial O2 consumption via high-resolution respirometry. Results showed that CLZ exposure decreased mitochondrial O2 consumption by 32% during complex I- and II-linked oxidative phosphorylation, while VPA exposure reduced it by 25% and 31% in combined CI+II- and CII-linked pathways, respectively. Combined exposure to CLZ and VPA caused similar reductions in O2 consumption, with a 25% decrease in combined CI+II-linked respiration and a 34% decrease in CII-linked respiration. The study highlighted that CLZ-induced cardiotoxicity may stem from mitochondrial dysfunction, with VPA potentially exacerbating these effects. The findings suggest that CLZ impairs oxidative phosphorylation without affecting mitochondrial coupling, possibly through direct inhibition of respiratory complexes or upstream enzymes. VPA's effects on mitochondrial function were also significant, though its role in exacerbating CLZ-induced cardiotoxicity remains unclear. The study emphasizes the need for further research into the mechanisms of CLZ and VPA-induced mitochondrial dysfunction to improve diagnostic and treatment guidelines for cardiotoxicity associated with these drugs.
adverseEvent: Clozapine and Sodium Valproate exposure caused mitochondrial dysfunction, reducing O2 consumption during oxidative phosphorylation. No specific adverse events such as death or drug toxicity were reported, but the study highlights the cardiotoxic potential of these drugs.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: The only antipsychotic that is approved and recommended for the treatment of otherwise treatment-resistant schizophrenia is clozapine (CLZ). Unfortunately, CLZ can cause serious cardiotoxicities such as myocarditis and cardiomyopathy. The co-administration of sodium valproate (VPA) during initiation is a well-established risk factor for the development of CLZ-induced myocarditis. However, the mechanisms behind these cardiac adverse effects and the role of VPA co-administration are not understood. Preliminary evidence for the development of cardiac mitochondrial dysfunction has previously been reported in both rodent models and immortalised cell lines. This investigation aimed to determine the functional effects of CLZ and VPA on human cardiac mitochondria to improve the current understanding of how cardiotoxicity develops. Small samples of human atrial tissue from consenting patients undergoing a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure were freshly collected and utilised to investigate the acute effects of each drug on mitochondrial O<sub>2</sub> consumption using high-resolution respirometry. Both drugs significantly decreased mitochondrial O<sub>2</sub> consumption by a magnitude of 32 % following CLZ exposure, 25 % following VPA exposure, and 25 % following combined CLZ+VPA exposure during complex I- and II-linked oxidative phosphorylation. These results demonstrate acute bioenergetic dysfunction with exposure to both drugs, alone and in combination. We propose that cardiac mitochondria become a key focus in future research seeking to improve the risk-predictive, diagnostic, and treatment guidelines surrounding CLZ-induced cardiotoxicity.

title: Hippocampal Inhibitory Interneuron-Specific DREADDs Treatment Alters mTORC1-4E-BP Signaling and Impairs Memory Formation.
abstract: The study investigates the role of mTORC1 signaling in memory formation, focusing on hippocampal inhibitory and excitatory neurons in mice. Using Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADDs), the researchers modulated neuronal activity through synthetic agonist Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO). The findings revealed that activation or inhibition of mTORC1 signaling in inhibitory neurons impaired long-term memory formation, as evidenced by changes in phosphorylation of downstream targets like 4E-BP1/2 and S6. However, similar modulation in excitatory neurons did not affect memory formation, highlighting the cell-type-specific role of mTORC1 signaling. The study underscores the importance of precise timing and activity-dependent regulation of mTORC1 signaling in inhibitory neurons for memory processes. While the study does not involve human subjects, it provides insights into potential therapeutic strategies for neurological disorders linked to dysregulated mTORC1 signaling, such as Alzheimer's disease and epilepsy. Clozapine-N-oxide was used to activate DREADDs, enabling spatiotemporal control of neuronal activity, which disrupted memory formation in inhibitory neurons but not in excitatory neurons.

aiInferenceData.Author_perspective: The article comments on the effect of Clozapine-N-oxide as a synthetic agonist for DREADDs, demonstrating its role in modulating mTORC1 signaling and its impact on memory formation in mice.
aiInferenceData.Abstract: Control of protein synthesis via the mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) is essential for learning and memory. However, the cell-type-specific and spatiotemporal regulation of this pathway during memory formation is not well understood. In this study, we expressed artificial human muscarinic M3 [hM3D(Gq)] or M4 [hM4D(Gi)] designer receptors exclusively activated by designer drugs (DREADDs) in hippocampal CA1 excitatory or inhibitory neurons of adult mice. We studied the impact of clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), a synthetic DREADDs agonist, on the mTORC1 pathway and long-term memory. hM3D(Gq) and hM4D(Gi) activate or inactivate, respectively, mTORC1 signaling in hippocampal interneurons, as indicated by the phosphorylation of its targets, eukaryotic initiation factor 4E-binding proteins (4E-BP1/2) and ribosomal protein S6 (S6). Activation of either hM3D(Gq) or hM4D(Gi) in mice immediately after training in memory tasks impaired long-term memory formation in inhibitory, but not in excitatory neurons. The findings underscore the importance of activity-dependent mTORC1-4E-BP1/2 signaling in hippocampal inhibitory interneurons for memory formation.
aiInferenceData.Title: Hippocampal Inhibitory Interneuron-Specific DREADDs Treatment Alters mTORC1-4E-BP Signaling and Impairs Memory Formation.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Huang Z, Mahmood N, Lacaille JC, Wiebe S, Sonenberg N. Hippocampal Inhibitory Interneuron-Specific DREADDs Treatment Alters mTORC1-4E-BP Signaling and Impairs Memory Formation. J Neurochem. 2025;169(3):e70048
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: The test subjects involved in this study are adult mice. The study utilized chemogenetic tools (DREADDs) to manipulate neuronal activity in the hippocampus of these mice. Specifically, the mice were genetically modified to express designer receptors activated by clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), a synthetic agonist, in either inhibitory or excitatory neurons.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), had an effect on the test subjects. It was used to activate or inhibit specific designer receptors in the hippocampal neurons of mice, which in turn modulated mTORC1 signaling pathways. This modulation disrupted long-term memory formation in inhibitory neurons but not in excitatory neurons. The study demonstrated that CNO-induced activation or inhibition of mTORC1 signaling in inhibitory neurons impaired memory tasks such as novel object location (NOL), object place learning (OPL), and novel object recognition (NOR).
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: The drug of study, clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), is conventionally used as a synthetic agonist for designer receptors in research settings. It is not used clinically for treating illnesses but is employed in experimental studies to selectively activate or inhibit engineered receptors (DREADDs). In this study, CNO was administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg to genetically modified mice expressing DREADDs in their hippocampal neurons. The drug was used to modulate neuronal activity and investigate its effects on memory formation.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links the drug of study, clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), to negative effects on memory formation in mice. Specifically, CNO-induced activation or inhibition of mTORC1 signaling in hippocampal inhibitory neurons impaired long-term memory tasks, highlighting its role in disrupting normal neuronal function.

title: Optimal Treatment of Magnetic Seizure Therapy (MST) in Patients with Clozapine-Resistant Schizophrenia (CRS).
abstract: The study focused on evaluating the efficacy and cognitive side effects of magnetic seizure therapy (MST) and modified electroconvulsive therapy (MECT) in patients with clozapine-resistant schizophrenia (CRS). Sixteen patients were randomized to receive either MST or MECT as add-on therapy to clozapine treatment, with 10 sessions conducted over 4 weeks. Clozapine doses were maintained between 300–600 mg/day throughout the study. Both MST and MECT significantly improved positive symptoms of schizophrenia, as measured by PANSS scores, with MST showing greater efficacy in reducing negative symptoms compared to MECT. Cognitive assessments revealed negligible adverse effects for both treatments, with MST demonstrating less impact on immediate memory than MECT. No serious adverse events were reported, and minor side effects such as headache or dizziness resolved within hours. The study concluded that MST is a promising alternative to MECT for CRS, with comparable efficacy and fewer cognitive side effects. Further research in larger clinical populations is recommended to validate these findings.
adverseEvent: Two patients reported minor adverse reactions, including headache and dizziness, which resolved within hours. No serious adverse events, drug toxicity, or detrimental effects were observed.

aiInferenceData.Patient_details: Patient details: Sixteen patients with clozapine-resistant schizophrenia (CRS) were enrolled in the study. Inclusion criteria included ages 18–55, DSM-5 diagnosis of schizophrenia, failure to respond to ≥2 adequate trials of first-line antipsychotic medication, persistence of moderate symptoms after clozapine trial, and specific PANSS scale scores. Exclusion criteria included severe physical disease, substance abuse, pregnancy, implants, recent MECT, or depressive symptoms.
aiInferenceData.Key_events: Key events: Patients were randomized into two groups to receive either magnetic seizure therapy (MST) or modified electroconvulsive therapy (MECT) as add-on therapy to clozapine treatment. Each group underwent 10 sessions over 4 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 4 and 8 weeks. The study aimed to evaluate clinical efficacy and cognitive side effects of MST and MECT in CRS patients.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
The study aims to compare the clinical efficacy and cognitive side effect of magnetic seizure therapy (MST) and modified electroconvulsive therapy (MECT) on clozapine resistant schizophrenia (CRS).

Sixteen patients with CRS were enrolled in this randomized, parallel-group, controlled clinical trial. Patients were randomly allocated to receive 10 sessions of add-on MST or MECT over 4 weeks (1:1 ratio) and continued clozapine therapy during the study. Efficacy and neurocognition were assessed at baseline, 4-week and 8-week follow-up.

(1) Clinical efficacy: MST significantly improved symptoms of schizophrenia from baseline to 4 weeks, as shown in PANSS total (p = 0.009), PANSS positive (p = 0.026), PANSS negative (p = 0.031) and PANSS general psychopathology (p = 0.023); we also observed significant reductions in PANSS total (p = 0.049) and PANSS positive (p = 0.037) at 8-week follow-up. MECT group also witnessed clinical improvement from baseline to 4-week in PANSS total (p = 0.035) and PANSS positive (p = 0.001); significant reduction in PANSS positive was also observed at 8-week follow-up (p = 0.041). From baseline to 8 weeks, PANSS negative had greater reduction in MST group compared with MECT group (p = 0.042). (2) Neurocognition: Pre-and post-treatment data showed no significant cognitive adverse effects in both groups. Immediate memory is better in patients who received MST than MECT at 4-week follow-up (p = 0.030).

In this pilot study, MST and MECT equally improved positive symptoms of CRS, while MST was more effective in relieving negative symptoms. Evidence showed negligible cognitive side effects in MST, with less adverse effect on immediate memory than MECT. As a promising alternative to MECT, MST requires further research in larger clinical population.
aiInferenceData.Title: Optimal Treatment of Magnetic Seizure Therapy (MST) in Patients with Clozapine-Resistant Schizophrenia (CRS).
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Xiang Q, Xu P, Zhai Z, Jia Y, Li C, Liu D. Optimal Treatment of Magnetic Seizure Therapy (MST) in Patients with Clozapine-Resistant Schizophrenia (CRS). Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2025;21491-501
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: Sixteen patients with clozapine-resistant schizophrenia (CRS) were involved in this study. These patients were exposed to the drug of study, Clozapine, as part of their ongoing treatment during the trial.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and psychotic disorders during Parkinson's disease when standard treatments fail. In this study, Clozapine was administered to patients with CRS, which aligns with its conventional use. The drug was not used in a non-conventional or off-label manner.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link the drug of study to any adverse effects or negative outcomes. It focuses on the efficacy and cognitive side effects of MST and MECT in CRS patients while continuing Clozapine therapy.

Both MST and MECT significantly improved positive symptoms of schizophrenia, as measured by PANSS scores, with MST showing greater efficacy in reducing negative symptoms compared to MECT. Cognitive assessments revealed negligible adverse effects for both treatments, with MST demonstrating less impact on immediate memory than MECT. No serious adverse events were reported, and minor side effects such as headache or dizziness resolved within hours. The study concluded that MST is a promising alternative to MECT for CRS, with comparable efficacy and fewer cognitive side effects. Further research in larger clinical populations is recommended to validate these findings.
authorPerspective: The article comments positively on the efficacy of MST and MECT in improving positive symptoms of CRS, with MST showing unique advantages in reducing negative symptoms and having fewer cognitive side effects compared to MECT. The study suggests MST as a promising alternative to MECT for CRS patients.

title: Default Mode Network, Disorganization, and Treatment-Resistant Schizophrenia.
abstract: The study investigates the default mode network (DMN) in schizophrenia, focusing on treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) and its relationship with disorganized thinking. Using resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging, the researchers analyzed DMN in 48 TRS patients, 76 non-TRS patients, and 64 healthy controls. The study found that TRS patients exhibited higher spatial loading on the DMN pattern but lower entropy compared to healthy controls, indicating excessive spatial contribution and exaggerated temporal stability of the DMN. Non-TRS patients showed intermediate alterations, suggesting a continuum between TRS and non-TRS groups. The study also found that higher spatial loading of the DMN was associated with more severe disorganization in patients. These findings suggest that TRS represents the severe end of a spectrum of DMN dysfunction in schizophrenia. While the study highlights the role of DMN alterations in schizophrenia, particularly in treatment-resistant cases, it does not provide specific data on drug administration, adverse events, or the role of Clozapine in the study.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Disorganized thinking is a prominent feature of schizophrenia that becomes persistent in the presence of treatment resistance. Disruption of the default mode network (DMN), which regulates self-referential thinking, is now a well-established feature of schizophrenia. However, we do not know if DMN disruption affects disorganization and contributes to treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS).

This study investigated the DMN in 48 TRS, 76 non-TRS, and 64 healthy controls (HC) using a spatiotemporal approach with resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging. We recovered DMN as an integrated network using multivariate group independent component analysis and estimated its loading coefficient (reflecting spatial prominence) and Shannon Entropy (reflecting temporal variability). Additionally, voxel-level analyses were conducted to examine network homogeneity and entropy within the DMN. We explored the relationship between DMN measures and disorganization using regression analysis.

TRS had higher spatial loading on population-level DMN pattern, but lower entropy compared to HC. Non-TRS patients showed intermediate DMN alterations, not significantly differing from either TRS or HC. No voxel-level differences were noted between TRS and non-TRS, emphasizing the continuum between the two groups. DMN's loading coefficient was higher in patients with more severe disorganization.

TRS may represent the most severe end of a spectrum of spatiotemporal DMN dysfunction in schizophrenia. While excessive spatial contribution of the DMN (high loading coefficient) is specifically associated with disorganization, both excessive spatial contribution and exaggerated temporal stability of DMN are features of schizophrenia that become more pronounced with refractoriness to first-line treatments.

title: Second-Generation Antipsychotic-Associated Serious Adverse Events in Women: An Analysis of a National Pharmacoepidemiologic Database.
abstract: The study analyzed adverse events associated with second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs) in women using the US adverse event reporting system. It focused on six SGAs, including clozapine, and examined five specific adverse events: Torsades de pointes (TdP), neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), tardive dyskinesia (TD), agranulocytosis (AG), and cerebrovascular adverse events (CVAE). The cohort consisted of 87,356 reports, with clozapine accounting for 25,096 (28.7%) of the cases. Females comprised 48.7% of the cohort, with a mean age of 48.6 years. The study found that females had significantly higher odds of hospitalization or death with TdP compared to males, with a reporting odds ratio (ROR) of 3.09. Other adverse events such as NMS, TD, AG, and CVAE were also analyzed, but TdP was highlighted as having worse outcomes in females. The study suggests that females exposed to SGAs, including clozapine, may be at higher risk for TdP and associated complications. Further research is recommended to confirm these findings.
adverseEvent: Females exposed to SGAs had higher odds of experiencing Torsades de pointes (TdP) and worse TdP-associated outcomes, including hospitalization or death. No specific drug toxicity or death was directly attributed to clozapine, but TdP was highlighted as a significant adverse event among females exposed to SGAs.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Women have historically been underrepresented in second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) clinical trials, accounting for less than 35% of participants, which raises concerns about the generalizability of the safety profile for these medications.

The US adverse event reporting system was queried for the dates January 1, 2019, to July 8, 2024, to examine the following 6 SGAs: aripiprazole, clozapine, olanzapine, quetiapine, risperidone, and ziprasidone. Reports were excluded if patients were under 18 years old, contained an unknown age or gender, or were duplicated. Five adverse events were examined: Torsades de pointes (TdP), neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), tardive dyskinesia (TD), agranulocytosis (AG), and cerebrovascular adverse events (CVAE). Counts of these events were noted, and reporting odds ratios (ROR) were calculated.

The total study cohort was 87,356 reports, consisting of aripiprazole (n = 10,715, 12.2%), clozapine (n = 25,096, 28.7%), olanzapine (n = 11,587, 13.3%), quetiapine (n = 28,746, 32.9%), risperidone (n = 10,467, 12%), and ziprasidone (n = 745, 0.9%). The cohort's mean age was 48.6 ± 18.5 years and comprised 42,584 females (48.7%). Most cases were reported by healthcare professionals (74,836, 85.7%). A total of 3,754 reports contained at least 1 of the 5 adverse events. The RORs among females compared to males for TdP (5.55, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 3.78-8.47), NMS (0.59, 95% CI = 0.53-0.65), TD (0.88, 95% CI = 0.76-1.02), AG (0.59, 95% CI = 0.51-0.70), and CVAE (1.12, 95% CI = 0.89-1.41) were observed. Females had a significantly higher odds of hospitalization or death with TdP compared to males (ROR = 3.09, 95% CI = 1.36-7.01).

Our findings suggest higher odds of TdP and worse TdP-associated outcomes among females exposed to SGAs compared to males. Further studies are needed to confirm these preliminary findings.

title: Unlocking the molecular mechanisms of anticancer and immunomodulatory potentials of cariprazine in triple negative breast cancer.
abstract: The study investigates the anticancer and immunomodulatory effects of Cariprazine (CAR), Olanzapine (OLZ), and Clozapine (CLZ) in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) models. TNBC is a challenging cancer type due to its invasive nature and lack of specific targets, often leading to drug resistance or relapse. The research focuses on repurposing antipsychotic drugs to address these challenges. In vitro experiments demonstrated that CAR, OLZ, and CLZ significantly inhibited TNBC cell proliferation by inducing mitochondrial apoptosis, G0/G1 cell cycle arrest, and suppressing autophagy. These effects were linked to molecular changes such as the downregulation of Bcl-2, p62, and pAKT, and the upregulation of Bax and active caspase 3. CAR also inhibited cell migration in MDA-MB-231 cells. In vivo, CAR showed potent anticancer activity in the 4T1 xenograft model, reducing tumor growth without adverse effects. It also modulated the immune response by promoting proinflammatory cytokines and increasing specific immune cell populations. Compared to other antipsychotics, 5-FU, and cisplatin, CAR exhibited the strongest anticancer activity, attributed to its ability to regulate apoptosis, autophagy, and immune responses. The study highlights CAR's therapeutic potential in TNBC treatment. However, the absence of human subject data limits the direct applicability of findings to clinical settings.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a highly invasive type of cancer, is difficult to treat due to insufficient specific targets and low survival rates. Current therapy often encounters drug resistance or relapse; thus, repurposing existing drugs could revolutionize cancer treatment. This study examined the anticancer effects of the antipsychotics Cariprazine (CAR), Olanzapine (OLZ), and Clozapine (CLZ), and the immunomodulatory potential of CAR, in vitro and in vivo in TNBC models. In vitro, CAR, OLZ, and CLZ significantly inhibited the proliferation of TNBC cells. This inhibition occurred via the induction of mitochondrial apoptosis, G0/G1 cell cycle arrest, and the suppression of autophagy, as evidenced by the down-regulation of Bcl-2, p62, and pAKT; the upregulation of Bax and active caspase 3; the decrease of ΔΨM; and the promotion of cytochrome c release. In addition, CAR inhibited MDA-MB-231 cells migration. In vivo, CAR inhibited tumor growth in the 4T1 xenograft model without causing adverse effects and resulted in the mRNA upregulation caspase 9, p53, p21, and Beclin-1. In addition, CAR influenced the immune response by promoting the production of proinflammatory cytokines TNF-α, IFN-γ, IL-17, and IL-1β and increasing the percentage of TNF-α<sup>+</sup>, IL-17<sup>+</sup>, IL-1β<sup>+</sup>, and IFN-γ<sup>+</sup> CD3<sup>+</sup> splenocytes. In conclusion, compared with other antipsychotics, 5-FU, and cisplatin, CAR exerted the most potent anticancer activity in TNBC in vitro and in vivo. This efficacy may be attributed to its ability to regulate apoptosis and autophagy, promote G0/G1 cell cycle arrest, and modulate antitumor immune response, suggesting its therapeutic potential in breast cancer.
aiInferenceData.Title: Unlocking the molecular mechanisms of anticancer and immunomodulatory potentials of cariprazine in triple negative breast cancer.

aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Clozapine is conventionally used as an antipsychotic medication, primarily administered orally to treat schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorders. In this study, Clozapine was administered to TNBC cells in vitro to investigate its anticancer effects. It was not specified whether Clozapine was used in vivo or how it was administered in the xenograft model. The drug was intended to treat TNBC by inhibiting cancer cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study mentions that Clozapine induced mitochondrial apoptosis, cell cycle arrest, and suppressed autophagy in TNBC cells, which are significant cellular events. While these effects are beneficial in the context of cancer treatment, they could potentially be linked to adverse effects in other contexts or systems.

title: Effects of chemogenetic virus injection and clozapine administration in spinal cord injury.
abstract: This study investigates the effects of chemogenetic stimulation using Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADDs) in conjunction with clozapine administration on spinal cord injury (SCI) in rats. The research focuses on enhancing motor recovery and neuroregeneration through targeted neuromodulation during the acute phase of SCI. Clozapine, administered at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg intraperitoneally, served as the ligand for DREADDs activation. Weekly behavioral assessments demonstrated significant improvements in motor skills and neuronal regeneration in treated animals compared to controls, with the most pronounced effects observed when stimulation was initiated early after injury. Histological analyses confirmed increased neuronal density, enhanced signaling protein expression, and reduced inflammatory markers in the treatment group. The study highlights the importance of early intervention, as acute-phase treatment yielded superior motor recovery and neuroregeneration outcomes compared to chronic-phase treatment. Clozapine's role in activating the Gq-signaling pathway was associated with increased intracellular calcium levels, promoting neuroplasticity and neuronal regeneration. The findings suggest that chemogenetic stimulation combined with clozapine administration effectively promotes neuroregeneration and motor recovery in SCI models. However, the study does not involve human subjects, and no adverse events or specific drug effects were reported.

aiInferenceData.Author_perspective: The article does not provide any specific opinion on the drug's effect on human subjects, but it highlights the potential of clozapine in enhancing neuroregeneration and motor recovery in animal models of SCI.
aiInferenceData.Abstract: Neuromodulation therapy using chemogenetic stimulation has shown potential in enhancing motor recovery and neuroregeneration following spinal cord injury (SCI). These therapeutic benefits are hypothesized to result from the promotion of neuroplasticity, particularly when administered during the acute phase of injury. In this study, we investigated the effects of chemogenetic stimulation using Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADDs) in conjunction with clozapine, a ligand for receptor activation. DREADDs enable targeted, reversible neuromodulation, facilitating the histological characterization of engineered neurons. We utilized these receptors to modulate G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling pathways, leading to the activation or inhibition of intracellular signaling. The objective was to determine whether the administration of DREADDs and clozapine (0.1 ​mg/kg) could enhance motor function and neuronal recovery, particularly when applied during the acute phase of SCI. Weekly behavioral assessments demonstrated significant improvements in motor skills and neuronal regeneration in treated animals compared to controls, with the most pronounced effects observed when stimulation was initiated early after injury. These enhancements in neuroplasticity were reflected in improved ladder rung test scores and Basso, Beattie, and Bresnahan (BBB) scale results in DREADDs-treated rats. Histological analyses, including immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining, Western blotting, and quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR), confirmed that the treatment group exhibited a higher density of neurons, increased signaling protein expression, and reduced inflammatory markers. These findings suggest that chemogenetic stimulation, particularly when administered during the acute phase, effectively promotes neuroregeneration and motor recovery. Future research should focus on assessing the long-term safety and efficacy of chemogenetic virus injection and clozapine administration, with an emphasis on the timing of intervention.
aiInferenceData.Title: Effects of chemogenetic virus injection and clozapine administration in spinal cord injury.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Kim JH, Hwang SY, Lee HL, Yoon SL, Ha Y, Lee HY, Ryu S. Effects of chemogenetic virus injection and clozapine administration in spinal cord injury. Neurotherapeutics. 2025;22(2):e00547
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: The test subjects involved in this study were male Sprague-Dawley rats. These rats were subjected to spinal cord injury (SCI) and subsequently treated with chemogenetic viruses and the drug of study, Clozapine, to investigate its effects on neuroregeneration and motor recovery.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, Clozapine, had a significant effect on the test subjects. It was used as a ligand to activate Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADDs), which facilitated targeted neuromodulation. The study demonstrated that Clozapine administration, in combination with chemogenetic stimulation, enhanced motor function recovery, neuronal regeneration, and neuroplasticity. It also reduced inflammatory markers and glial scar formation, promoting remyelination and functional recovery in the injured spinal cord.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Clozapine is conventionally used as an antipsychotic medication for the treatment of schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorders, typically administered orally. In this study, Clozapine was administered intraperitoneally at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg daily to rats with spinal cord injuries. It was used as a ligand to activate DREADDs for the purpose of promoting neuroregeneration and motor recovery following SCI.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study mentions potential off-target effects of Clozapine due to its broad pharmacological profile, including actions on other CNS receptors such as dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine, and histamine receptors. While no behavioral side effects were observed in this study, the possibility of off-target effects is acknowledged, necessitating careful consideration of dosing and safety in future research.

title: Negative Symptoms in Schizophrenia: An Update on Research Assessment and the Current and Upcoming Treatment Landscape.
abstract: This article is a narrative review focusing on the negative symptoms of schizophrenia, which include diminished emotional expression, avolition, alogia, anhedonia, and asociality. These symptoms are noted to be poorly responsive to current treatments and are significant contributors to functional disability in schizophrenia. The review discusses various mechanisms of action and potential treatments, including antipsychotics, glutamatergic modulators, serotonin receptor modulators, anti-inflammatory agents, antidepressants, pro-dopaminergic modulators, acetylcholine modulators, oxytocin, and phosphodiesterase inhibitors. Among the medications mentioned, clozapine is highlighted as a potentially beneficial off-label treatment for negative symptoms in schizophrenia, alongside other drugs like cariprazine, olanzapine, and amisulpride. The article emphasizes that while no definitive gold-standard treatment exists for broadly defined negative symptoms, these medications are generally tolerable and could be considered for off-label trials. The review also discusses investigational treatments such as NMDAR agonists, muscarinic agonists, and LB-102, which are still under study. Suggestions for future research include improving study designs to reduce placebo effects, using more precise rating scales for negative symptoms, and focusing on individuals with predominant negative symptoms. The article does not provide specific data on human subjects, drug administration, or adverse events, as it is a review rather than a clinical study.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: The negative symptoms of schizophrenia include diminished emotional expression, avolition, alogia, anhedonia, and asociality, and due to their low responsiveness to available treatments, are a primary driver of functional disability in schizophrenia. This narrative review has the aim of providing a comprehensive overview of the current research developments in the treatment of negative symptoms in schizophrenia, and begins by introducing the concepts of primary, secondary, prominent, predominant, and broadly defined negative symptoms. We then compare and contrast commonly used research assessment scales for negative symptoms and review the evidence for the specific utility of widely available off-label and investigational treatments that have been studied for negative symptoms. Mechanism of action/putative treatments included are antipsychotics (D<sub>2</sub>R antagonists), N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) and other glutamatergic modulators, serotonin receptor (5-HTR) modulators, anti-inflammatory agents, antidepressants, pro-dopaminergic modulators (non-D<sub>2</sub>R antagonists), acetylcholine modulators, oxytocin, and phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibitors. With the caveat that no compounds are definitively proven as gold-standard treatments for broadly defined negative symptoms, the evidence base supports several potentially beneficial off-label and investigational medications for treating negative symptoms in schizophrenia, such as monotherapy with cariprazine, olanzapine, clozapine, and amisulpride, or adjunctive use of memantine, setrons such as ondansetron, minocycline, and antidepressants. These medications are widely available worldwide, generally tolerable and could be considered for an off-label, time-limited trial for a predesignated period of time, after which a decision to switch or stay can be made based on clinical response. Among investigational medications, NMDAR agonists, muscarinic agonists, and LB-102 remain under study. Suggestions for future research include reducing placebo effects by designing studies with a smaller number of high-quality study sites, potentially increasing the use of more precise rating scales for negative symptoms, and focused studies in people with predominant negative symptoms.

title: Inhibition of the glutamatergic PVT-NAc projections attenuates local anesthetic-induced neurotoxic behaviors.
abstract: The study investigates the role of the paraventricular thalamus (PVT)-nucleus accumbens (NAc) projections in neurotoxicity induced by ropivacaine, a local anesthetic agent, using a mouse model. Ropivacaine was administered intraperitoneally at a dose of 58 mg/kg to construct the local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) model in C57BL/6 mice. The study identified neural projections from the PVT to the NAc using retrograde tracers and viruses. Inhibitory viruses were injected into the mice model to assess the effects of specific inhibition of the PVT-NAc pathway on neurological behaviors in the presence of clozapine-N-oxide. The inhibition of the pathway was evaluated through immunofluorescence staining of c-Fos-positive neurons and calcium signals in CaMKIIa neurons. The study successfully identified a circuit connecting the PVT and NAc, and ropivacaine administration was found to activate this pathway, leading to seizures. Specific inhibition of NAc-projecting CaMKII neurons in the PVT reduced neuronal activity in the NAc and decreased ropivacaine-induced neurotoxicity. The findings suggest a dedicated PVT-NAc circuit that regulates local anesthetic-induced neurotoxicity and provide insights into potential mechanisms for the treatment and prevention of LAST. The study does not involve human subjects, and no adverse events related to clozapine were reported.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Local anesthetic-induced neurotoxicity contributes to perioperative nerve damage; however, the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Here, we investigated the role of the paraventricular thalamus (PVT)-nucleus accumbens (NAc) projections in neurotoxicity induced by ropivacaine, a local anesthetic agent.

Ropivacaine (58 mg/kg, intraperitoneal administration) was used to construct the local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) mice model. We first identified neural projections from the PVT to the NAc through the expression of a retrograde tracer and virus. The inhibitory viruses (rAAV-EF1α-DIO-hm4D(Gi)-mCherry-WPREs: AAV2/retro and rAAV-CaMKII-CRE-WPRE-hGh: AAV2/9) were injected into the mice model to assess the effects of the specific inhibition of the PVT-NAc pathway on neurological behaviors in the presence of clozapine-N-oxide. The inhibition of the PVT-NAc pathway was evaluated by immunofluorescence staining of c-Fos-positive neurons and Ca<sup>2+</sup> signals in CaMKIIa neurons.

We successfully identified a circuit connecting the PVT and NAc in C57BL/6 mice. Ropivacaine administration induced the activation of the PVT-NAc pathway and seizures. Specific inhibition of NAc-projecting CaMKII neurons in the PVT was sufficient to inhibit the neuronal activity in the NAc, which subsequently decreased ropivacaine-induced neurotoxicity.

These results reveal the presence of a dedicated PVT-NAc circuit that regulates local anesthetic-induced neurotoxicity and provide a potential mechanistic explanation for the treatment and prevention of LAST.
aiInferenceData.Title: Inhibition of the glutamatergic PVT-NAc projections attenuates local anesthetic-induced neurotoxic behaviors.

Additionally, clozapine-N-oxide was used in conjunction with inhibitory viruses to assess the effects of specific pathway inhibition.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: 2. The drug of study, clozapine-N-oxide, was used in this study to facilitate the inhibition of the PVT-NAc pathway in the mice model. However, the study does not indicate that clozapine-N-oxide itself induced any medical event or adverse effect in the test subjects. Its role was limited to enabling the inhibition of specific neural pathways. No Drug Effect.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: 3. Clozapine-N-oxide is conventionally used as a pharmacological tool in neuroscience research, particularly in chemogenetic studies, to activate or inhibit designer receptors exclusively activated by designer drugs (DREADDs). It is not typically used for treating illnesses in patients. In this study, clozapine-N-oxide was administered to mice to inhibit the PVT-NAc pathway as part of the investigation into ropivacaine-induced neurotoxicity.
aiInferenceData.Justification: 5. The study does not link clozapine-N-oxide to any negative or adverse effects within the test subjects. Its role was solely to facilitate pathway inhibition in the experimental model.

title: A case of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis associated with clozapine-induced agranulocytosis.
abstract: This article describes the first documented case of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) associated with clozapine-induced agranulocytosis (CLIA). A 51-year-old man with treatment-resistant schizophrenia developed CLIA nine months after starting clozapine therapy. The patient presented with fever, cough, leukopenia, and neutropenia, leading to the diagnosis of CLIA. Clozapine was discontinued, and empirical treatments with filgrastim and cefepime were initiated. Serum β-D-glucan and Aspergillus galactomannan antigen tests confirmed IPA, and chest CT revealed nodular lesions. Antifungal therapy was switched from micafungin to voriconazole, which led to resolution of the fungal infection and improvement in neutropenia and fever. aiInferenceData.Abstract: Clozapine-induced agranulocytosis (CLIA) is a rare but serious complication. Fever associated with CLIA is typically treated with broad-spectrum antimicrobials, but empiric antifungal therapy is rarely used. While bacterial and viral infections have been reported in CLIA cases, no cases of fungal infections complicated by CLIA have been documented. We report the first case of CLIA complicated by invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in a patient with schizophrenia. The diagnosis of IPA was made using serum β-D-glucan, Aspergillus galactomannan antigen tests, and chest computed tomography (CT). We present a case of a 51-year-old man with schizophrenia who developed CLIA complicated by IPA. The patient, diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia, was started on clozapine, but 9 months later he presented with fever, cough, leukopenia, and neutropenia. Clozapine was discontinued, and empirical treatments with cefepime and filgrastim were initiated. Serum β-D-glucan and Aspergillus galactomannan antigen tests were positive, and chest CT showed well-circumscribed nodules, leading to a probable diagnosis of IPA. Antifungal therapy was switched from micafungin to voriconazole according to guidelines. His neutropenia and fever improved, and he was re-transferred to a psychiatric hospital. CLIA can be complicated by fungal infections. When patients with CLIA present with fever, fungal infections, including IPA, should be considered in the differential diagnosis. Serological tests, including β-D-glucan and Aspergillus galactomannan, are useful for the diagnosis of IPA as well as the appropriate use of antifungal agents in patients with CLIA.
aiInferenceData.Title: A case of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis associated with clozapine-induced agranulocytosis.

title: Bugs Bugging the Body and the Brain: A Case of a Bed Bug Infestation Progressing to Delusions of Parasitosis Treated With Clozapine.
abstract: This article discusses a unique case of a 50-year-old man with bipolar-type schizoaffective disorder who developed delusional parasitosis following a bed bug infestation in his group home. The patient presented with auditory and tactile hallucinations, believing bugs were controlling his brain. He was admitted to the psychiatric department, where his medication regimen was adjusted, including an increase in clozapine dosage from 25 mg to 75 mg twice daily and valproic acid from 500 mg to 750 mg twice daily. Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, played a significant role in treating the patient’s symptoms, which is notable as delusional parasitosis is typically treated with second-generation antipsychotics like risperidone or olanzapine. During his three-week hospitalization, the patient’s auditory hallucinations resolved by day 7, and no new hematologic adverse effects were noted. After discharge, the patient continued his prescribed medications and therapy sessions, reporting no recurrence of delusional parasitosis symptoms or hallucinations. The study highlights clozapine’s potential as an effective treatment for refractory delusional parasitosis, despite its known risks of severe side effects such as agranulocytosis. The case underscores the importance of tailored treatment regimens and patient compliance in managing psychiatric conditions.

He was monitored for three weeks, during which his symptoms improved, and he was discharged with ongoing therapy and follow-ups.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Delusions of parasitosis, also known as delusional parasitosis or Ekbom syndrome, is a rare psychiatric disorder characterized by a fixed belief in a bug infestation, despite the absence of clinical evidence. It often co-occurs with other psychiatric conditions such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. In this case, a 50-year-old man with bipolar-type schizoaffective disorder developed delusional parasitosis after a bed bug infestation in his group home. His inadequate adherence to prescribed medications likely exacerbated his symptoms. Treatment involved the consistent administration of clozapine and valproic acid, with dosage adjustments and close monitoring by a psychiatric team. Notably, clozapine's successful role in this case is unique, as delusional parasitosis is typically treated with second-generation atypical antipsychotics.
aiInferenceData.Title: Bugs Bugging the Body and the Brain: A Case of a Bed Bug Infestation Progressing to Delusions of Parasitosis Treated With Clozapine.

title: Clozapine-Induced Acute Pericarditis and Cardiac Tamponade: Early Recognition Improves Clinical Outcomes.
abstract: This article discusses a case of clozapine-induced acute pericarditis and cardiac tamponade in a 26-year-old male with schizoaffective disorder. The patient had been started on clozapine four months prior, titrated to 250 mg daily, and began experiencing symptoms of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath one week after discharge from a psychiatric facility. Diagnostic imaging revealed a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade physiology, necessitating emergent pericardiocentesis and pericardial drain placement. Treatment with ibuprofen and colchicine led to resolution of symptoms, and clozapine was discontinued during hospitalization and upon discharge. The article emphasizes the importance of early recognition and monitoring of cardiovascular side effects associated with clozapine, including pericarditis and cardiac tamponade, which are rare but potentially life-threatening. The authors recommend implementing cardiac monitoring protocols for patients on clozapine to prevent such adverse effects. The case highlights the need for further research to establish consensus guidelines for optimal cardiac monitoring during clozapine therapy.
adverseEvent: The adverse events included acute pericarditis and cardiac tamponade due to pericardial effusion, which were attributed to clozapine. Emergent pericardiocentesis and pericardial drain placement were required to manage the life-threatening condition. Clozapine was discontinued, and the patient recovered following treatment with ibuprofen and colchicine.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Clozapine is approved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Many cardiovascular side effects are associated with clozapine, including QTc prolongation and myocarditis, which is a black box warning. Few cases of pericarditis have been reported in recent literature. We report a case of a 26-year-old male with schizoaffective disorder who presented with sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient was started on clozapine three months prior to his current presentation. The workup revealed a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade physiology and signs consistent with acute pericarditis. He required emergent pericardiocentesis and pericardial drain placement. Symptoms resolved after treatment with ibuprofen and colchicine. This case report highlights the importance of early diagnosis of life-threatening cardiovascular complications associated with clozapine, especially acute pericarditis and cardiac tamponade due to pericardial effusion. We strongly recommend implementing monitoring protocols to prevent this potentially life-threatening adverse effect in patients taking clozapine.

aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Clozapine is conventionally used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and psychotic disorders during Parkinson's disease when standard treatments fail. aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links Clozapine to life-threatening cardiovascular side effects, including acute pericarditis and cardiac tamponade, and the drug was used in an off-label manner.

title: Challenging the impostor: a scoping review of the pharmacological management of Capgras syndrome in Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies dementia.
abstract: The article is a scoping review that examines the pharmacological management of Capgras syndrome (CS) in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) and Lewy Body Dementia (LBD). It highlights that most PD patients with CS experienced cognitive decline and visual hallucinations. These patients were managed by reducing dopaminergic therapy and prescribing neuroleptics, including quetiapine, clozapine, and pimavanserin, which often led to improvement. Neuroleptics were also used in LBD patients, but their efficacy was inconsistent. The review emphasizes the lack of robust evidence for the pharmacological treatment of CS in these conditions and calls for future prospective studies to establish evidence-based guidelines. Clozapine is specifically mentioned as one of the neuroleptics used in the management of CS, and it appears to have contributed to improvement in some cases. However, the variability in efficacy, particularly in LBD patients, underscores the need for further research.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Capgras syndrome (CS) is a delusional misidentification phenomenon increasingly reported in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) and Lewy Body Dementia (LBD). Aim of the present scoping review was to provide an overview on current evidence on the pharmacological treatment of CS in PD and LBD, identifying knowledge gaps in the literature.

The following databases were consulted: PubMed, Google Scholar, the Cochrane Database and Web of Science.

The search query covered a time period from 1976 until 2022. Fourteen studies on PD (11 single case reports, 3 case series) and five on LBD (all single case reports) met the inclusion criteria. Most PD patients with CS had cognitive decline and visual hallucinations, and were managed by reducing dopaminergic therapy and prescribing neuroleptics (quetiapine, clozapine or pimavanserin), which often resulted in improvement. Neuroleptics have also been used in LBD, but with variable efficacy.

Although neuroleptics and dopaminergic dose adjustments appear to be beneficial for CS in PD and LBD, robust evidence is lacking. Future prospective studies are essential to establish evidence-based guidelines for this challenging syndrome.

title: Cross-titration from risperidone to clozapine utilizing clozapine serum concentrations: A case report.
abstract: This article describes the case of a 68-year-old female patient with schizophrenia and Parkinson's disease who was admitted to the hospital after a fall. She was taking risperidone and fluoxetine at the time of admission. During her hospital stay, the patient underwent a cross-titration from risperidone to clozapine over 17 days, with the final dose of clozapine being 75 mg daily. The transition was guided by serum clozapine levels and clinical status, particularly in the context of multiple drug-drug interactions. The study highlights the lack of evidence-based guidelines for transitioning patients between antipsychotics, especially when drug interactions are involved. It emphasizes the potential utility of serum clozapine levels in guiding dose adjustments during antipsychotic cross-titration. The patient was successfully transitioned without any reported adverse events or complications, demonstrating the feasibility of this approach in clinical practice.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Clozapine and risperidone are second-generation antipsychotics used in the treatment of schizophrenia. There are no guidelines on cross-titration of antipsychotics and, additionally, there is a paucity of published data to support the potential utility of using serum drug levels to guide dosing in these situations.

A 68-year-old female patient with a history of schizophrenia, taking risperidone and fluoxetine, and a recent diagnosis of Parkinson's disease was admitted to the hospital after a fall at home. During the patient's hospital stay, utilizing serum clozapine levels as guidance, the patient was cross-titrated from risperidone 12 mg daily to a final dose of clozapine 75 mg daily over the span of 17 days, in the setting of multiple possible drug-drug interactions.

There is no evidence-based guidance on transitioning patients from one antipsychotic to another especially in the setting of drug-drug interactions. In this case, the patient was successfully transitioned from risperidone to clozapine using serum clozapine levels and clinical status to guide decision-making.

Utilizing serum clozapine levels may be helpful in guiding dose changes during antipsychotic cross-titration, especially when multiple drug interactions are involved.

title: Clozapine for Parkinson's disease psychosis in a septuagenarian: a nightmare turned into bliss.
abstract: The article discusses the use of Clozapine in treating Parkinson's disease psychosis (PDP) in an elderly patient. Parkinson's disease psychosis is characterized by confusion, visual hallucinations, and delusions, which significantly impact the quality of life for both patients and caregivers. Classic neuroleptics are known to worsen motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease, making the search for effective atypical antipsychotics crucial. While Pimavanserin is the only approved drug for PDP, its limited availability poses challenges. Clozapine, on the other hand, is highlighted for its excellent antipsychotic profile, cost-effectiveness, and easy accessibility, without exacerbating motor symptoms. The article describes a septuagenarian patient with PDP who showed an excellent response to low-dose Clozapine, improving their quality of life. However, specific details about the patient's condition, timeline, and adverse events are not provided due to the unavailability of the full article. The abstract emphasizes Clozapine's potential in transcending boundaries to improve the lives of PD patients with psychosis, but no adverse events or specific outcomes are mentioned.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Parkinson's disease psychosis, characterized by confusion, visual hallucinations, and delusions is a nightmare for the patients and caregivers. Classic neuroleptics aggravate the motor symptoms, hence the need for an effective atypical antipsychotic. Currently Pimavanserin is the only approved drug for Parkinson's disease psychosis (PDP), however it is not readily available. Clozapine with its excellent anti psychotic profile, without worsening of motor features, cost effectiveness and easy availability transcends all boundaries in improving the Quality of life in PD patients with psychosis. We describe an elderly patient with PDP with an excellent response to low dose clozapine.

Classic neuroleptics are known to worsen motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease, making the search for effective atypical antipsychotics crucial. While Pimavanserin is the only approved drug for PDP, its limited availability poses challenges. Clozapine, on the other hand, is highlighted for its excellent antipsychotic profile, cost-effectiveness, and easy accessibility, without exacerbating motor symptoms. The article describes a septuagenarian patient with PDP who showed an excellent response to low-dose Clozapine, improving their quality of life. However, specific details about the patient's condition, timeline, and adverse events are not provided due to the unavailability of the full article. The abstract emphasizes Clozapine's potential in transcending boundaries to improve the lives of PD patients with psychosis, but no adverse events or specific outcomes are mentioned.
authorPerspective: The article comments positively on Clozapine's effect on Parkinson's disease psychosis, highlighting its excellent antipsychotic profile, cost-effectiveness, and ability to improve the quality of life without worsening motor symptoms.
vancouverCitation: Makani J, Kumar A, Hussain I, Kumar N, Joshi D. Clozapine for Parkinson's disease psychosis in a septuagenarian: a nightmare turned into bliss. Neurol Sci. 2025;46(3):1415-
approvedIndication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and psychotic disorders occurring during Parkinson's disease when standard treatments fail. In this study, Clozapine was administered to an elderly patient with Parkinson's disease psychosis (PDP), which aligns with its conventional use. Therefore, this does not qualify as off-label use.
justification: The study does not mention any adverse effects or negative outcomes linked to the drug of study. It describes an excellent response to low-dose Clozapine in the patient.

title: Clozapine impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion partly by increasing plasma 5-HT levels due to the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake in mice.
abstract: The study investigates the effects of clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, on glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) and glucose tolerance in mice. Clozapine was found to impair GSIS and glucose tolerance by increasing plasma serotonin (5-HT) levels through the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake. Elevated 5-HT levels were shown to impair GSIS by activating islet 5-HTR3a receptors, while clozapine's antagonistic effect on islet 5-HTR2a receptors also contributed to GSIS impairment. The study utilized normal mice, high-fat diet-fed mice, INS-1 cells, and HEK293-OCT1 cells to explore the mechanisms underlying clozapine-induced hyperglycemia. The findings suggest that clozapine-induced GSIS impairment and hyperglycemia may be partly explained by increased plasma 5-HT levels due to the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake. This research provides insights into the metabolic side effects of clozapine and potentially other atypical antipsychotics.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Patients taking atypical antipsychotics (AAPs), especially clozapine, are often associated with hyperglycaemia. Here, clozapine served as a representative agent for investigating how AAPs induce hyperglycaemia. In normal mice and mice fed a high fat diet (HFD), clozapine impaired glucose tolerance and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) following intraperitoneal glucose administration and increased plasma 5-HT levels. Intraperitoneal 5-HT administration also impaired glucose tolerance and GSIS in mice. In INS-1 cells, high 5-HT levels impaired GSIS, which was attenuated by the 5-HTR<sub>3</sub> antagonist tropisetron or by silencing 5-HTR<sub>3a</sub>. The 5-HTR<sub>2a</sub> agonist TCB2 attenuated clozapine-induced GSIS impairment. Silencing 5-HTR<sub>2a</sub> or the 5-HTR<sub>2a</sub> antagonist ketanserin impaired GSIS. In mice, 5-HT administration impaired GSIS, which was attenuated by tropisetron but aggravated by clozapine. Clozapine increased plasma [<sup>2</sup>H]5-HT exposure following intravenous administration to mice. In HEK293-OCT1 cells, clozapine inhibited [<sup>2</sup>H]5-HT and MPP<sup>+</sup> uptake. Clozapine or OCT1 silencing impaired 5-HT metabolism in mouse primary hepatocytes, demonstrating that clozapine increased plasma 5-HT levels via the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake. Liver-specific silencing of OCT1 increased plasma [<sup>2</sup>H]5-HT exposure and 5-HT levels and impaired GSIS and glucose tolerance in mice. In conclusion, clozapine impaired GSIS and glucose tolerance by increasing plasma 5-HT levels via the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake. Increased 5-HT impaired GSIS by activating islet 5-HTR<sub>3a</sub>. The antagonistic effect of clozapine on islet 5-HTR<sub>2a</sub> also contributed to GSIS impairment. The finding that clozapine-induced GSIS impairment was attributed to increased 5-HT levels via the inhibition of OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake may partly explain hyperglycaemia caused by other AAPs.

Clozapine also inhibited OCT1-mediated hepatic 5-HT uptake, leading to increased plasma 5-HT levels, which further impaired GSIS and glucose tolerance.

In this study, clozapine was administered to mice, and its effects on glucose tolerance and insulin secretion were investigated. The study aimed to understand the mechanism behind clozapine-induced hyperglycaemia.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links clozapine to negative effects, specifically impaired glucose tolerance and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which are adverse effects associated with hyperglycaemia.
