title: Endocannabinoid system alterations in schizophrenia: association with cannabis use and antipsychotic medication.
abstract: The study investigated the modulation of the endocannabinoid system (ECS) in individuals with schizophrenia, focusing on the influence of cannabis use and antipsychotic medications, including clozapine. Ninety-three individuals were divided into three groups: patients with schizophrenia using clozapine (treatment-resistant), patients using other antipsychotics, and controls. Proteins and metabolites involved in ECS pathways, such as AEA, 2-AG, and CB2 receptor levels, were measured in peripheral blood. Cannabis use was found to significantly lower 2-AG plasma levels, while non-clozapine antipsychotics were marginally associated with changes in CB2 receptor levels. The study did not provide specific data on adverse events or complications related to clozapine use. The findings suggest that cannabis use and non-clozapine antipsychotics may influence ECS modulation, which could be relevant to the physiopathology of schizophrenia. Further research is needed to explore the role of the ECS in schizophrenia and its interaction with antipsychotic medications.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Determining peripheral modulation of the endocannabinoid system (ECS) may be important for differentiating individuals with schizophrenia. Such differentiation can also be extended to subgroups of individuals, those who use cannabis and antipsychotic medications, particularly those who are treatment resistant. Patients and controls were recruited from the outpatient clinic of the Psychosis Group of the University of São Paulo, Brazil. A final sample of 93 individuals was divided into 3 groups: patients with schizophrenia using clozapine (treatment-resistant) (n = 29), patients with schizophrenia using another antipsychotic (n = 31), and controls (n = 33). By measuring the proteins and metabolites involved in the ECS pathways in the peripheral blood, AEA (anandamide), 2-AG (2-arachidonoyl ethanolamine), and CB2 receptor (peripheral) were quantified. Individuals reporting lifetime cannabis use had lower 2-AG plasma levels (p = 0.011). Regarding the CB2 receptor, the values of patients with schizophrenia and controls were similar, but those of patients using antipsychotics other than clozapine differed (p = 0.022). In generalized linear models to control for confounders, the use of cannabis remained the only factor that significantly influenced 2-AG levels. The relationship for non-clozapine antipsychotics as the only factor related to CB2 changes was marginally significant. We found for the first time that cannabis use and non-clozapine antipsychotic medication are potentially involved in the modulation of the ECS, specifically influencing 2-AG endocannabinoid and CB2 receptor levels. More studies regarding the ECS are needed since it has been increasingly related to the physiopathology of schizophrenia.

title: Parabrachial  neurons influence aversive and appetitive taste function.
abstract: The study investigates the role of parabrachial (PB) neurons expressing the Calca gene in taste-guided behaviors using chemogenetic methods in mice. Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO) was administered to activate inhibitory designer receptors (hM4Di) expressed in PB-Calca neurons. The study found that CNO administration reduced avoidance of the bitter taste stimulus quinine in hM4Di mice, with variability in response magnitude across individuals. However, responses to another bitter stimulus, cycloheximide, were unaffected. Additionally, CNO selectively reduced sucrose preference in male hM4Di mice, indicating a sex-dependent effect on appetitive taste-guided behavior. The findings suggest that PB-Calca neurons play a role in both aversive and appetitive taste responses, with their involvement in appetitive taste being influenced by sex. The study highlights the complex role of PB-Calca neurons in taste processing and their potential to encode opposing valences through frequency-dependent neurotransmission.

aiInferenceData.Drug_effect: Drug effect: summary: Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO) was used to activate inhibitory designer receptors in mice, leading to altered licking behavior in response to taste stimuli. The drug influenced aversive and appetitive taste responses, with sex-dependent effects observed in sucrose preference.
aiInferenceData.Summary: The study investigates the role of parabrachial (PB) neurons expressing the Calca gene in taste-guided behaviors using chemogenetic methods in mice. Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO) was administered to activate inhibitory designer receptors (hM4Di) expressed in PB-Calca neurons. The study found that CNO administration reduced avoidance of the bitter taste stimulus quinine in hM4Di mice, with variability in response magnitude across individuals. However, responses to another bitter stimulus, cycloheximide, were unaffected. Additionally, CNO selectively reduced sucrose preference in male hM4Di mice, indicating a sex-dependent effect on appetitive taste-guided behavior. The findings suggest that PB-Calca neurons play a role in both aversive and appetitive taste responses, with their involvement in appetitive taste being influenced by sex. The study highlights the complex role of PB-Calca neurons in taste processing and their potential to encode opposing valences through frequency-dependent neurotransmission.
aiInferenceData.Author_perspective: The article comments on the effects of Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO) on taste-guided behaviors in mice, highlighting its influence on aversive and appetitive taste responses and the sex-dependent effects observed in sucrose preference.
aiInferenceData.Abstract: The parabrachial (PB) nucleus participates in taste processing and integration with other senses. PB neurons that express the Calca gene support sensory-integrative responses, albeit only limited data have addressed their influence on taste. Here we studied how chemogenetic dampening of PB-Calca neurons impacted mouse orosensory preferences for diverse taste stimuli in brief-access fluid exposure tests, which capture oral sensory/tongue control of licking behavior. Intracranial delivery of Cre-dependent viruses in female and male Calca Cre/+ mice induced expression of the inhibitory designer receptor hM4Di:mCherry (hM4Di mice) or fluorophore mCherry alone (mCherry mice) in PB-Calca neurons. Several weeks later, hM4Di and mCherry mice entered brief-access tests where they could lick taste solutions on discrete seconds-long trials. Stimuli included the behaviorally avoided, but functionally different, bitter taste stimuli quinine (0 [water], 0.1, 0.3, and 1.0 mM) and cycloheximide (0, 0.001, 0.003, and 0.01 mM), and the appetitive sugar sucrose (0, 100, 300, 500, and 1000 mM). Both hM4Di and mCherry mice received the hM4Di ligand clozapine-N-oxide (CNO, 5 mg/kg, i.p.) prior to daily tests performed by blinded experimenters. With CNO, hM4Di mice displayed greater average licking (i.e., less avoidance) of quinine (p < 0.05), but not cycloheximide (p > 0.3), than mCherry mice, implying PB-Calca neurons variably influence orosensory responses across bitter stimuli. Moreover, male hM4Di mice selectively showed reduced mean licking preferences for sucrose under CNO (p < 0.05). These data suggest that PB-Calca neurons participate in both aversive and appetitive taste-guided behaviors, with their role in appetitive taste dependent on sex.
aiInferenceData.Title: Parabrachial Calca neurons influence aversive and appetitive taste function.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Lemon CH, Li J, Ali MSS, Ngum NM, Zumpano KT, Roberts CJ. Parabrachial Calca neurons influence aversive and appetitive taste function. bioRxiv. 2025;
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: Yes, there is a test subject involved in this study. The test subjects are adult female and male mice genetically modified to express Cre-dependent genes (CalcaCre/+ mice). These mice were divided into experimental groups (hM4Di mice) and control groups (mCherry mice) to study the effects of chemogenetic dampening of PB-Calca neurons on taste-guided behaviors.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: Yes, the drug of study, Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), had an effect on the test subjects. CNO was administered to activate the inhibitory designer receptor hM4Di expressed in PB-Calca neurons of hM4Di mice. This resulted in altered taste-guided behaviors, including reduced avoidance of the bitter taste stimulus quinine and sex-dependent reductions in sucrose taste preference in male hM4Di mice.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used as an antipsychotic medication for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorders. It is typically administered orally to human patients. In this study, Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), a derivative of Clozapine, was administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) at a dose of 5 mg/kg to mice. It was used as a ligand to activate the inhibitory designer receptor hM4Di expressed in PB-Calca neurons, aiming to study its effects on taste-guided behaviors.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links the drug of study, Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), to negative effects, specifically sex-dependent reductions in sucrose taste preference in male hM4Di mice. This suggests that the drug-induced suppression of PB-Calca neurons can influence appetitive taste-guided behaviors adversely.

authorPerspective: The article comments on the effects of Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO) on taste-guided behaviors in mice, highlighting its influence on aversive and appetitive taste responses and the sex-dependent effects observed in sucrose preference.
vancouverCitation: Lemon CH, Li J, Ali MSS, Ngum NM, Zumpano KT, Roberts CJ. Parabrachial Calca neurons influence aversive and appetitive taste function. bioRxiv. 2025;
testSubject: Yes, there is a test subject involved in this study. The test subjects are adult female and male mice genetically modified to express Cre-dependent genes (CalcaCre/+ mice). These mice were divided into experimental groups (hM4Di mice) and control groups (mCherry mice) to study the effects of chemogenetic dampening of PB-Calca neurons on taste-guided behaviors.
aoiDrugEffect: Yes, the drug of study, Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), had an effect on the test subjects. CNO was administered to activate the inhibitory designer receptor hM4Di expressed in PB-Calca neurons of hM4Di mice. This resulted in altered taste-guided behaviors, including reduced avoidance of the bitter taste stimulus quinine and sex-dependent reductions in sucrose taste preference in male hM4Di mice.
approvedIndication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used as an antipsychotic medication for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorders. It is typically administered orally to human patients. In this study, Clozapine-N-oxide (CNO), a derivative of Clozapine, was administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) at a dose of 5 mg/kg to mice. It was used as a ligand to activate the inhibitory designer receptor hM4Di expressed in PB-Calca neurons, aiming to study its effects on taste-guided behaviors.

r3FormData.D.7: All study mice were adult CalcaCre/+ mice generated by crossing homozygous CalcaCre mice with C57BL/6J mice. Before surgery, mice were group housed with ad libitum access to standard mouse chow and filtered water.
r3FormData.D.7.1.r: Patient 1: Adult CalcaCre/+ mice, both female and male, were used in the study. They were surgically prepared and tested for taste-guided behaviors.

title: A Review of Clinical Advances and Challenges in Clozapine-Induced Myocarditis.
abstract: Clozapine is highlighted as the first-choice treatment for TRS due to its efficacy in managing schizophrenia symptoms, reducing suicide risk, and minimizing extrapyramidal side effects. However, its use is limited by severe adverse effects, including clozapine-induced myocarditis (CIM). The article reviews the clinical features, mechanisms, and management strategies for CIM, emphasizing its insidious onset and nonspecific symptoms such as fever, tachycardia, and fatigue. These symptoms can be misinterpreted during the initial titration of clozapine, complicating early detection. The pathogenesis of CIM is linked to immune-mediated mechanisms, oxidative stress, and catecholamine-induced injury. Discontinuation of clozapine is the primary treatment, with supportive care involving diuretics, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and glucocorticoids in severe cases. The article discusses the challenges of reintroducing clozapine after CIM, noting a 60% success rate for re-challenge under stringent monitoring. It highlights the importance of slow titration, close monitoring of biomarkers like CRP and troponin, and individualized treatment regimens to minimize the risk of CIM. The review underscores the need for further research on CIM's pathogenesis, diagnostic criteria, and management protocols, as well as the development of globally harmonized guidelines for clozapine therapy.
adverseEvent: The article discusses adverse events related to clozapine therapy, particularly myocarditis and cardiomyopathy. CIM can lead to severe outcomes such as malignant arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. Rapid titration of clozapine and co-administration with other medications are identified as risk factors for CIM. The article emphasizes the importance of early detection and management to prevent fatal outcomes.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Currently, the treatment of schizophrenia remains primarily pharmacological, with approximately 30% of patients diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS). Clozapine continues to be the first choice treatment for this subgroup of patients. As the preferred treatment, clozapine offers clear advantages in efficacy; however, its complex and troublesome adverse effects pose significant challenges for psychiatrists. Common side effects include granulocytopenia, intestinal obstruction, myocarditis, cardiomyopathy, constipation, and seizures. The first two complications are easier to manage due to the availability of laboratory monitoring, and improved management strategies are now in place in clinical practice. In recent years, clozapine-induced myocarditis (CIM) has gained considerable attention because of its potentially severe outcomes. However, the mechanism behind its lethality remains unclear, and there is no widely accepted consensus or treatment guideline, which complicates the implementation of targeted prevention in clinical practice. This review aims to summarize the clinical manifestations of CIM, explore the underlying mechanisms, and discuss recent advances in monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment, with the goal of offering constructive recommendations for future clinical management.

title: Successful Clozapine Treatment for Treatment-Resistant Schizophrenia With Zinc Deficiency Severe Anemia: A Case Report.
abstract: This case report discusses the successful treatment of a 51-year-old Japanese woman with treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) using clozapine, despite complications of severe anemia potentially linked to zinc deficiency. The patient had been hospitalized multiple times due to worsening psychiatric symptoms and had previously failed treatment with various antipsychotics. Clozapine therapy was initiated, leading to a reduction in psychiatric symptoms, as evidenced by a decrease in PANSS scores. However, the patient developed severe anemia over a nine-week period, with hemoglobin levels dropping to 8.4 g/dL. Despite dose adjustments, anemia progressed to 6.7 g/dL at 19 weeks, necessitating multiple blood transfusions. Detailed blood tests revealed zinc deficiency, prompting zinc supplementation, which improved hemoglobin levels and allowed the continuation of clozapine therapy at a therapeutic dose. The patient's psychiatric symptoms remained stable, and no further anemia progression was observed. This case highlights the potential link between clozapine-induced anemia and zinc deficiency, suggesting the need for regular monitoring of serum zinc levels in patients undergoing clozapine therapy. While clozapine demonstrated efficacy in managing TRS, its use requires careful consideration due to potential adverse effects, including hematologic complications. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanism of clozapine-induced anemia and its relationship with zinc deficiency.
adverseEvent: Severe anemia occurred, potentially triggered by clozapine therapy. Zinc deficiency was identified as a contributing factor. The anemia required multiple blood transfusions and zinc supplementation for management.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug approved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS). Despite its high efficacy for TRS, clozapine is associated with several serious adverse effects, such as neutropenia and diabetes, so it requires vigilant monitoring. Severe anemia has also been documented as a rare but serious complication with an unclear mechanism. We present a case report of severe anemia potentially associated with zinc deficiency during clozapine therapy.

A 51-year-old woman was diagnosed with TRS without physical complications. Zinc deficiency was identified as a potential contributing factor. Zinc supplementation improved her hemoglobin levels, enabling the patient to continue clozapine at a therapeutic dose. The patient has remained stable, with no recurrence of anemia.

Clozapine is a highly effective antipsychotic, despite side effects including blood dyscrasias. While zinc deficiency is most likely to be implicated in clozapine-induced anemia, the exact mechanism remains unclear. Further research is required to explore this relationship between clozapine and zinc decrement.

title: The lateral habenula regulates stress-related respiratory responses via the monoaminergic system.
abstract: The study investigated the role of the lateral habenula (LHb) in stress-induced respiratory responses using anesthetized Wistar male rats. Electrical stimulation of the LHb increased respiratory frequency and minute ventilation. The involvement of the monoaminergic system was analyzed by administering receptor antagonists. Clozapine, a dopaminergic receptor antagonist, suppressed LHb-induced respiratory responses, while methysergide, a serotonergic receptor antagonist, enhanced respiratory frequency and suppressed thoracic movement amplitude. To further explore the dopaminergic modulation, muscimol, a GABA receptor agonist, was administered to inhibit the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which contains dopaminergic neurons receiving inputs from the LHb. Bilateral inhibition of the VTA almost abolished LHb-induced respiratory responses, suggesting that LHb activation accelerates respiration primarily through dopaminergic neurons in the VTA, with suppressive modulation by the serotonergic system. The study highlights the LHb-monoaminergic pathway, particularly the LHb-VTA circuit, as a critical regulator of respiratory movements during stress events. Clozapine's role in suppressing LHb-induced respiratory responses underscores its potential impact on stress-related respiratory modulation.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Psychologic stress induces behavioral and autonomic responses such as acceleration of respiration. The lateral habenula (LHb) is noted to be involved in stress-induced behavioral responses. However, its involvement in stress-induced respiratory responses is unknown. In this study, we aimed to analyze whether and how the LHb regulates respiration. Electrical stimulation of the LHb of anesthetized Wistar male rats increased respiratory frequency and minute ventilation, calculated by respiratory frequency × thoracic movement amplitude. Systemic administration of a dopaminergic receptor antagonist, clozapine, suppressed the LHb-induced respiratory responses. On the other hand, administration of a serotonergic receptor antagonist, methysergide, significantly accelerated the LHb-induced increase in respiratory frequency, together with suppressing the thoracic movement amplitude. To clarify the source of dopaminergic modulation, we inhibited the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which contains dopaminergic neurons and receives inputs from the LHb, by administering microinjections of a GABA<sub>A</sub> agonist, muscimol. The bilateral inhibition of the VTA almost abolished the LHb-induced respiratory responses. These results suggest that LHb activation causes respiration acceleration, mainly mediated by dopaminergic neurons in the VTA and suppressively modulated by the serotonergic system. Neural circuits originating in the LHb may be a key modulator for respiration during psychological stress.
aiInferenceData.Title: The lateral habenula regulates stress-related respiratory responses via the monoaminergic system.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Mizukami R, Matsumoto M, Koganezawa T. The lateral habenula regulates stress-related respiratory responses via the monoaminergic system. Pflugers Arch. 2025;477(3):441-52
aiInferenceData.Test_subject: The test subjects involved in this study were anesthetized Wistar male rats. These rats were subjected to electrical stimulation of the lateral habenula (LHb) and systemic administration of various receptor antagonists, including the drug of study, clozapine.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, clozapine, had an effect on the test subjects. Specifically, systemic administration of clozapine, a dopaminergic receptor antagonist, strongly suppressed the LHb-induced respiratory responses in the rats. This indicates that clozapine played a role in modulating the respiratory effects induced by LHb activation.

attributability: Attributability: The study demonstrated that clozapine suppressed LHb-induced respiratory responses, while methysergide enhanced respiratory frequency and suppressed thoracic movement amplitude. Muscimol inactivation of the VTA abolished LHb-induced respiratory responses, indicating the involvement of dopaminergic neurons in the VTA.
drugEffect: Drug effect: Clozapine suppressed LHb-induced respiratory responses, methysergide enhanced respiratory frequency while suppressing thoracic movement amplitude, and muscimol abolished LHb-induced respiratory responses.
summary: The study investigated the role of the lateral habenula (LHb) in stress-induced respiratory responses using anesthetized Wistar male rats. Electrical stimulation of the LHb increased respiratory frequency and minute ventilation. The involvement of the monoaminergic system was analyzed by administering receptor antagonists. Clozapine, a dopaminergic receptor antagonist, suppressed LHb-induced respiratory responses, while methysergide, a serotonergic receptor antagonist, enhanced respiratory frequency and suppressed thoracic movement amplitude. To further explore the dopaminergic modulation, muscimol, a GABA receptor agonist, was administered to inhibit the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which contains dopaminergic neurons receiving inputs from the LHb. Bilateral inhibition of the VTA almost abolished LHb-induced respiratory responses, suggesting that LHb activation accelerates respiration primarily through dopaminergic neurons in the VTA, with suppressive modulation by the serotonergic system. The study highlights the LHb-monoaminergic pathway, particularly the LHb-VTA circuit, as a critical regulator of respiratory movements during stress events. Clozapine's role in suppressing LHb-induced respiratory responses underscores its potential impact on stress-related respiratory modulation.
authorPerspective: The article comments on the effects of clozapine, methysergide, and muscimol on LHb-induced respiratory responses, highlighting the suppressive role of clozapine and the modulatory effects of methysergide and muscimol. It concludes that the LHb regulates respiratory movements via the monoaminergic system, particularly through dopaminergic neurons in the VTA.

title: Antipsychotic drug dosing and study discontinuation in schizophrenia: A systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis.
abstract: This systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis investigated the relationship between antipsychotic drug doses and discontinuation rates in patients with acute exacerbation of schizophrenia and related disorders. The study analyzed data from 136 trials involving 44,126 participants, focusing on discontinuation due to inefficacy and side effects. Clozapine was among the antipsychotics studied, and its dose-response curve showed a plateau, suggesting no additional benefit from increasing doses beyond specific points. The study highlighted that amisulpride, cariprazine, olanzapine, and quetiapine demonstrated U-shaped dose-response curves, where higher doses led to increased discontinuation rates due to side effects. For clozapine and other drugs like aripiprazole, asenapine, brexpiprazole, paliperidone, and risperidone, the dose-response curves plateaued, indicating optimal dosing thresholds. The study emphasized the importance of identifying these thresholds to maximize treatment adherence and minimize discontinuation. It also noted that discontinuation due to side effects sharply increased with higher doses for most antipsychotics. The findings suggest that future studies should separately present disease-related and side-effect-related dropouts due to adverse events to better understand the impact of antipsychotic dosing on treatment adherence.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
High discontinuation rates compromise the effectiveness of treatment regimens for schizophrenia, because consistent medication adherence is essential for the efficacy of antipsychotics. Understanding the relationship between antipsychotic doses and discontinuation rates is important. This study explores this relationship to identify doses that maximize treatment adherence and minimize discontinuation.

We systematically searched multiple electronic databases for fixed-dose RCTs assessing 20 antipsychotics in patients with acute exacerbation of schizophrenia and related disorders. We analyzed dose-response relationships using a one-stage dose-response meta-analysis within a frequentist framework, employing restricted cubic splines to model the relationships. The primary outcome was discontinuation for any reason, and secondary outcomes were discontinuation due to inefficacy and side effects.

Analysis of 136 trials involving 44,126 participants revealed various dose-response relationships for antipsychotics. For the primary outcome, all-cause discontinuation, amisulpride, cariprazine, olanzapine (Zyprexa), and quetiapine demonstrated U-shaped curves, indicating optimal dosing thresholds where further increases in dosage led to heightened discontinuation rates, possibly due to side effects. Aripiprazole, asenapine, brexpiprazole, clozapine, paliperidone, and risperidone (Risperdal) had plateaus, suggesting no additional benefit from increasing doses beyond specific points. For haloperidol, iloperidone, lumateperone, lurasidone, sertindole, and ziprasidone, the dose-response curves did not reach a plateau within the examined doses. Inefficacy discontinuation curves were similar to total discontinuation. Most discontinuation for side-effects curves showed sharp increases in side-effects associated with higher doses.

Dose discontinuation curves varied between the antipsychotics and included U-shaped, monotonic, and hyperbolic patterns. Future studies should consistently present disease-related and side-effect-related dropouts due to adverse events separately.

title: Predictors of clozapine concentration and psychiatric symptoms in patients with schizophrenia.
abstract: This study investigated the clinical and genetic factors influencing clozapine pharmacokinetics and psychiatric symptoms in patients with schizophrenia. A total of 45 patients were enrolled, with clozapine administered for 18 weeks. Blood samples were collected at specific intervals to assess clozapine concentration, and symptom severity was evaluated using the PANSS. Smoking status and cumulative clozapine dose were significantly associated with clozapine concentration, while genetic factors such as SNPs in CYP2D6, UGT1A1, and UGT1A4 also played a role. Psychiatric symptoms, as measured by PANSS scores, were influenced by BMI, total bilirubin levels, and genetic variations in ABCB1 and DRD4. The study highlighted the importance of individualized clozapine treatment strategies, considering both clinical and genetic predictors. Adverse effects were monitored, but no specific adverse events were detailed in the study. The findings suggest that genetic and clinical factors should be considered to optimize clozapine dosing and improve treatment outcomes for schizophrenia patients.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Clozapine has superior efficacy to other antipsychotics, especially in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, its pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics vary largely among patients. We aimed to evaluate the clinical and genetic factors associated with the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of clozapine in patients with schizophrenia. Blood samples for clozapine pharmacokinetic assessment were collected from patients with schizophrenia at weeks 2 (visit 2), 8 (visit 3), and 18 (visit 4) from the initiation of clozapine treatment. The Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) score was assessed at baseline (visit 1) and visits 3 and 4. Linear mixed models were used to identify the clinical and genetic variables associated with the clozapine concentration and total PANSS score. A total of 45 patients were included in the pharmacogenomic analysis. Owing to the small sample size, we categorized concomitant medications into four groups. However, individual drugs may have different effects on clozapine concentration. Clozapine concentration was significantly associated with smoking status and cumulative clozapine dose. Clozapine concentration was significantly associated with five single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in three genes (rs28371726 and rs202102799 in CYP2D6, rs4148323 and rs34946978 in UGT1A1, and rs2011404 in UGT1A4). Furthermore, follow-up time, body mass index, and total bilirubin levels were significantly associated with the total PANSS scores. The PANSS score was significantly associated with four SNPs in two genes (rs7787082 and rs10248420 in ABCB1 and rs2133251840 and rs762502 in DRD4). This study suggests potential clinical and genetic predictors of clozapine concentration and psychiatric symptoms in patients with schizophrenia treated with clozapine. With further investigations in diverse populations, our findings may provide important information on variables to be considered in individualized clozapine treatment.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Clozapine-induced hypersalivation is one of the most common bothersome adverse reactions of clozapine. The management strategies for this condition remain inadequately studied and understood. The objective of the study is to compare the effectiveness and tolerability of (1) trihexyphenidyl 5 mg/d, (2) clonidine 0.15 mg/d, or (3) a reduction of clozapine dosage by 25 to 50 mg/d for managing clozapine-induced hypersalivation.

A randomized, open-label, non-placebo-controlled clinical trial was conducted from December 2023 to May 2024. Eligible patients were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 groups. Primary outcomes were assessed using the Drooling Severity and Frequency Scale (DSFS) and the Nocturnal Hypersalivation Rating Scale (NHRS) at baseline, week 4, and week 8. Quality of life assessed using the pharmaceutical therapy for quality of life short version and adverse drug reactions were recorded as secondary outcomes.

A total of 67 patients were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 treatment groups. By week 8, significant reductions in DSFS and NHRS scores were observed in all groups, with clonidine showing the greatest improvement. Trihexyphenidyl was also effective, whereas reducing clozapine dose resulted in more modest improvements. Quality of life improved significantly across all groups, with the greatest improvement observed in the clonidine group. The most common adverse effects were dry mouth, constipation, drowsiness, and dizziness.

Clonidine and trihexyphenidyl appear to be more effective options for managing clozapine-induced hypersalivation compared to clozapine dose reduction.

title: Assessment and Management of Patients at Risk for Suicide: Synopsis of the 2024 U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and U.S. Department of Defense Clinical Practice Guidelines.
abstract: The article provides a synopsis of the updated 2024 U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and U.S. Department of Defense Clinical Practice Guidelines for assessing and managing patients at risk for suicide. It highlights the recommendations for primary care physicians regarding the evaluation and management of military members and veterans. The VA/DOD Evidence-Based Practice Work Group systematically reviewed literature from 1 April 2018 to 15 March 2023 and developed 24 recommendations using the GRADE system. The guidelines emphasize the use of validated tools to identify populations at higher risk for suicide-related behaviors, cognitive behavioral therapy to reduce suicide attempts and suicidal ideation, and periodic communications as a prevention strategy. Pharmacologic treatments, including clozapine for schizophrenia and ketamine infusion for major depressive disorder, are also recommended for managing suicide risk. While the article mentions clozapine as a treatment option, it does not provide specific details about its administration, duration, or effects on human subjects. Additionally, no adverse events or complications related to clozapine are reported in the provided text. The synopsis underscores the importance of evidence-based approaches in suicide prevention but does not elaborate on the outcomes or effectiveness of the mentioned treatments.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) updated the 2019 joint clinical practice guideline (CPG) for assessing and managing patients who are at risk for suicide. This synopsis provides primary care physicians with a summary of the updated 2024 recommendations regarding evaluation and management of military members and veterans at risk for suicide.

In 2023, the VA/DOD Evidence-Based Practice Work Group convened to develop a joint VA/DOD guideline, including clinical stakeholders, which conformed to the National Academy of Medicine's tenets for trustworthy CPGs. The Work Group drafted 12 key questions, reviewed systematically identified literature (1 April 2018 to 15 March 2023), evaluated the evidence, created algorithms, and advanced 24 recommendations in accordance with the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) system.

Despite insufficient evidence to recommend for or against suicide risk screening programs as a means for reducing suicide attempts or deaths, the VA/DOD Work Group identified validated tools that could be used to identify populations at higher risk for suicide-related behaviors. Cognitive behavioral therapy was also recommended for reducing the risk for suicide attempts and decreasing suicidal ideation among those with a history of suicidal behavior or a history of self-directed violence. Periodic communications after previous suicide attempts were also recommended as a prevention strategy. Pharmacologic treatments, such as clozapine or ketamine infusion, also have a role in the management of suicide risk among those with schizophrenia or major depressive disorder, respectively.

title: Investigating Why Comparing Intravenous and Perineural Dexamethasone Is Scientifically Unfounded.
abstract: The article focuses on the pharmacological differences between intravenous and perineural administration of dexamethasone in regional anesthesia. It argues that comparing these routes is scientifically unfounded due to their distinct mechanisms of action and clinical effects. Intravenous dexamethasone is described as having systemic anti-inflammatory and antiemetic effects, which are beneficial in enhanced recovery pathways. In contrast, perineural dexamethasone creates a high-concentration depot at the neural interface, providing localized benefits such as prolonged block reliability, reduced vascular uptake, and neuroprotection through antiedema, antifibrotic, microcirculatory, and antineurotoxic actions. The article critiques the methodological flaw of milligram dosing parity across routes and suggests concentration- or exposure-matched designs for future studies. It recommends using intravenous dexamethasone for systemic modulation and perineural dexamethasone for extending block duration and nerve protection, with combined use being synergistic when both aims are relevant. The editorial reframes the debate from competition to context-specific integration to align practice with pharmacology and improve patient-centered outcomes. No specific adverse events or complications related to dexamethasone are mentioned.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Dexamethasone is a widely used adjuvant in regional anesthesia, yet debate persists over whether intravenous (IV) and perineural routes are interchangeable. This editorial argues that head-to-head comparisons are mechanistically unsound and clinically misleading. IV dexamethasone distributes systemically after cardiopulmonary transit, yielding low, variable target-site bioavailability at the nerve; systemic anti-inflammatory and antiemetic effects within enhanced recovery pathways dominate its benefits. Perineural dexamethasone creates a high-concentration depot at the neural interface, prolonging block reliability through reduced vascular uptake and a locally anti-inflammatory microenvironment, while conferring neuroprotection via antiedema, antifibrotic, microcirculatory, and antineurotoxic actions. Published studies reporting either superiority of perineural dosing or equivalence between routes likely reflect heterogeneity in populations, procedures, timing, anesthetic strategies, and adjuvant regimens rather than true pharmacologic parity. Methodological parity of milligram dosing across routes is a key flaw; concentration- or exposure-matched designs are needed. Clinically, IV dexamethasone should be used for systemic modulation (including postoperative nausea and vomiting reduction), whereas perineural dexamethasone should be selected to extend block duration and protect the nerve; combined use can be synergistic when both aims matter. Reframing the debate from competition to context-specific integration aligns practice with pharmacology and may improve patient-centered outcomes.

This use does not align with the conventional uses listed, and therefore qualifies as off-label use.

title: Polymeric nanoparticles functionalized with dexamethasone attenuate the osteogenic inhibition induced by titanium debris.
abstract: The study investigates the impact of titanium debris on bone regeneration potential and evaluates the efficacy of dexamethasone-doped polymeric nanoparticles (DexNPs) combined with calcium phosphate (CaP) in overcoming the inhibitory effects of titanium debris. The research was conducted on six New Zealand-bred rabbits, where four critical bone defects were created on their skulls. Different biomaterials were placed in the defects, including unfilled control, calcium phosphate granules, titanium debris combined with calcium phosphate, and dexamethasone-doped polymeric nanoparticles combined with calcium phosphate and titanium debris. After six weeks, the rabbits were euthanized, and the bone architecture was analyzed radiographically and histologically. The study found that titanium debris reduced bone healing, while the presence of DexNPs restored defect closure values and improved osteogenic potential. Bone filling area and bone area fraction were highest in the presence of DexNPs, indicating enhanced bone regeneration. The study highlights the potential of DexNPs in improving bone healing in the presence of titanium debris. However, as the study involves animal subjects, no human data or adverse events are reported.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Implantoplasty is sometimes performed to eliminate the contaminated titanium surface of peri-implantitis affected implants. Bone regeneration treatments are performed in conjuction with implantoplasty. The aim of this study was to evaluate if produced titanium debris alter the bone-regeneration potential and if dexamethasone-doped polymeric nanoparticles, combined with calcium phosphate, may help to overcome this situation.

Four critical bone defects were performed on six New Zealand-bred rabbit skulls. In each of the four bone defects, the following biomaterials were placed: 1) unfilled (control), 2) calcium phosphate granules (CaP), 3) titanium debris (Tid) and CaP, 4) dexamethasone-doped polymeric nanoparticles (DexNPs) doped onto CaP and Tid. After six weeks, animals were euthanized and the bone architecture was evaluated radiographically with micro computed tomography through BoneJ pluging and ImageJ script, and histologically after Von Kossa staining.

Bone defects filled with CaP plus Tid showed lower defect closure than those filled with CaP. The presence of DexNPs restored the defect closure values, being similar to those of the CaP group. Bone filling area and bone area fraction attained the highest values in the presence of DexNPs. Aligned new bone islands were formed and grew up around the CaP granules, infiltrating its porous structure. In the CaP+Tid group a lower bone ingrowth was formed. When applying DexNPs, bone bridging processes were located surrounding the CaP biomaterial.

The presence of Tid reduces the bone healing and DexNPs doped on CaP produced an increase in the osteogenic potential, improving the bone defect closure.
aiInferenceData.Title: Polymeric nanoparticles functionalized with dexamethasone attenuate the osteogenic inhibition induced by titanium debris.

aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, dexamethasone, was incorporated into polymeric nanoparticles (DexNPs) and applied to bone defects in the rabbits. The study found that DexNPs improved the osteogenic potential and bone defect closure, restoring values similar to those of the calcium phosphate (CaP) group. DexNPs enhanced bone filling area and bone area fraction, promoting bone bridging processes and aligned new bone formation around the CaP granules. Thus, the drug had a positive effect on the test subjects.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Dexamethasone is conventionally used as a corticosteroid to treat inflammatory conditions, autoimmune diseases, and certain types of cancer. It is typically administered orally, intravenously, or via injection, depending on the condition being treated. In this study, dexamethasone was administered in the form of polymeric nanoparticles (DexNPs) doped onto calcium phosphate granules and titanium debris. It was given to rabbits with critical bone defects to evaluate its potential in improving bone regeneration and defect closure.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link dexamethasone to any negative or adverse effects. Instead, it highlights its positive impact on bone regeneration and defect closure in the test subjects.

title: From liquid nanocapsules to 3D-printed medicines: effect of freeze-drying on dexamethasone release and intestinal permeation.
abstract: The study investigates the impact of freeze-drying on dexamethasone-loaded ethylcellulose nanocapsules (NC-EC-DEX) and their subsequent use in 3D-printed medicines. The research focuses on the physicochemical properties, drug release behavior, and intestinal permeation of these nanocapsules using in vitro Caco-2 cell models. The freshly prepared NC-EC-DEX demonstrated nanometric size, narrow size distribution, negative zeta potential, and specific drug content. Mannitol was tested as a cryoprotectant, with the highest concentration ensuring full recovery of nanometric size after freeze-drying. The freeze-dried formulation exhibited sustained drug release and slower permeation across Caco-2 cells while maintaining high cell viability. The freeze-dried powder was further processed into solid dosage forms via semi-solid extrusion 3D printing, showcasing a continuous workflow from liquid nanosuspension to stable intermediate powder and ultimately to 3D-printed medicines. This study highlights the potential of 3D printing as a downstream manufacturing solution for nanomedicines, providing a versatile platform for innovative drug delivery systems. No human subjects were involved, and no adverse events were reported.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Liquid nanocapsule (NC) suspensions are recognised as effective carriers for drug delivery. Freeze-drying offers a valuable strategy to enhance their storage stability and enable their incorporation into solid dosage forms, thereby facilitating clinical translation. However, limited information is available regarding the effects of freeze-drying on the drug release behaviour and intestinal permeation of drug-loaded NCs. In this study, dexamethasone-loaded ethylcellulose NCs (NC-EC-DEX) were produced and subjected to freeze-drying to assess the influence of this process on their physicochemical and in vitro performance using Caco-2 cell models. The freshly prepared NC-EC-DEX showed a nanometric size (136 ± 3 nm), narrow size distribution (polydispersity index, 0.10 ± 0.02), negative zeta potential (-16.4 ± 1.3 mV), and drug content of 0.47 mg mL<sup>-1</sup>. Mannitol was tested as a cryoprotectant at concentrations of 3 %, 5 %, and 10 % (w/v), with only the highest concentration ensuring full recovery of nanometric size after drying (232 ± 19 nm; polydispersity index, 0.33 ± 0.02). The freeze-dried formulation (FD<sub>NC-EC-DEX</sub>) exhibited a more sustained drug release and slower permeation across Caco-2 cells compared with the liquid suspension, while maintaining high cell viability (>80 %). This preservation of nanoscale behaviour after reconstitution was essential to demonstrate that the freeze-dried powder could function as an intermediate suitable for further processing. The freeze-dried powder was subsequently used as feedstock for the fabrication of solid dosage forms via semi-solid extrusion 3D printing, thereby establishing a rational technological sequence in which the liquid nanosuspension is first stabilised through lyophilisation and then transformed into a printable matrix. Overall, this study provides a proof of concept for a continuous workflow, from liquid nanosuspension to a more stable intermediate powder, and ultimately to 3D-printed solid dosage forms-highlighting its potential for processing powders with limited flowability, such as those obtained through freeze-drying. This integrated approach strengthens the technological justification for employing 3D printing as a downstream manufacturing solution for nanomedicines, establishing a versatile technological platform for the development of innovative 3D-printed nanomedicines.

title: Vitexin ameliorates PM2.5-triggered pulmonary toxicity through dual modulation of endoplasmic reticulum stress and ferroptosis pathways.
abstract: The study investigates the protective effects of Vitexin (VI), a natural flavonoid, against PM2.5-induced pulmonary toxicity through dual modulation of endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS) and ferroptosis pathways. The research combines in vivo and in vitro approaches. In the in vivo study, PM2.5-exposed mice were treated with Vitexin (15-60 mg/kg) or dexamethasone (0.125 mg/kg) via oral gavage for 8 weeks, followed by biospecimen collection post-euthanasia. The in vitro study involved BEAS-2B cells pretreated with Vitexin and exposed to PM2.5 supernatant, with cellular responses assessed. Molecular simulations revealed Vitexin's high-affinity binding to GPX4, stabilizing it and reducing ferroptotic cell death. Vitexin activates the NRF2/HO-1/NQO1 pathway to enhance antioxidant capacity and suppresses ERS via the PERK/eIF2α/ATF4/CHOP axis, collectively reducing lipid peroxidation and ferroptosis. While the study mentions dexamethasone as a comparative treatment, no specific adverse events or human subjects are discussed. The findings highlight Vitexin's potential as a protective agent against air pollution-related lung injury.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) primarily damages the respiratory system, leading to lung injury with limited therapeutic options. Recent studies suggest that ferroptosis and endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS) play pivotal roles in PM2.5-induced pulmonary injury. This integrated study, combining in vivo and in vitro approaches, evaluated the protective potential of Vitexin (VI), a natural flavonoid, against PM2.5-mediated lung injury, focusing on its mechanisms involving ERS and ferroptosis. For the in vivo arm, PM2.5-exposed mice received VI (15-60 mg/kg) or dexamethasone (0.125 mg/kg) via oral gavage over 8 weeks, with systemic biospecimen collection (serum/BALF/lung) post-euthanasia at endpoint. Concurrently, in vitro, BEAS-2B cells were pretreated with 30 μM VI and then exposed to PM2.5 supernatant (400 μg/mL) for 24 h, with cellular responses evaluated after standardized culture and viability assessment via CCK-8 assay. Meanwhile, we employed molecular simulations, which predicted a high-affinity binding between VI and GPX4, suggesting direct stabilization. Experimental investigations elucidated that VI alleviates PM2.5-triggered ferroptosis through a dual-pathway synergy: it activates the NRF2/HO-1/NQO1 pathway to enhance antioxidant capacity, while suppressing endoplasmic reticulum stress via the PERK/eIF2α/ATF4/CHOP axis. The attenuation of ERS, in turn, upregulates system Xc<sup>－</sup> activity and GPX4 expression. These integrated actions collectively reduce lipid peroxidation and attenuate ferroptotic cell death. In summary, VI significantly exerted a protective effect against PM2.5-induced lung injury by inhibiting ERS-mediated ferroptosis, highlighting its promise as a protective agent against air pollution-related pulmonary damage.

Both test subjects were utilized to evaluate the protective effects against PM2.5-induced pulmonary injury.

It was intended to treat PM2.5-induced pulmonary injury.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link Dexamethasone to any negative or adverse effects within the test subjects. The focus was on evaluating Vitexin's protective effects, and no adverse effects of Dexamethasone were mentioned.

title: Inhibition of Joint Inflammation in Rheumatoid Arthritis by Wuwei Ganlu Medicinal Bath Granules via Blocking Toll-like Receptor 4/Nuclear Factor-kappa B and NOD-like Receptor Pyrin Domain-containing 3 Signaling.
abstract: The study investigates the anti-inflammatory effects of Wuwei Ganlu Medicinal Bath Granules (WGMG) in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats, focusing on its pharmacological mechanisms through the TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 signaling pathways. WGMG, derived from Tibetan medicine, consists of five medicinal plants and was administered to CIA rats via medicinal bath treatment at varying doses for 28 days. The study identified 89 compounds in WGMG, with 18 common compounds found in both serum and synovial fluid, including kaempferol and trans-ferulic acid. The findings revealed that WGMG significantly reduced arthritis scores, paw swelling, and spleen index in CIA rats, alleviating symptoms of arthritis. Histopathological analysis showed reduced synovial hyperplasia, inflammatory cell infiltration, and cartilage erosion. WGMG also inhibited serum levels of NF-κB, TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-18 while enhancing IL-4 levels. Mechanistically, WGMG downregulated the protein and mRNA expression of TLR4, NF-κB, NLRP3, ASC, and caspase-1, with high-dose WGMG demonstrating therapeutic efficacy comparable to dexamethasone. The study highlights the potent anti-inflammatory activity of WGMG, attributed to its bioactive components kaempferol and trans-ferulic acid, and suggests its potential as a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. No human subjects were involved in this study, and no adverse events were reported.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Lum medicinal bathing is a usage of external therapy in the Tibetan medicine system, Sowa Rigpa, specifically the application of herbal decoction to derive the bioactive compounds through skin absorption. Wuwei Ganlu (Five-Flavored Nectar) is one of the formulations used in treatment which is especially useful for the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The Four-Tantras (rGyud-bzhi), 8th-12th centuries, is the source of the preparation and clinical use of Wuwei Ganlu decoctions. In today's society, a standardized Tibetan herbal preparation called the Wuwei Ganlu Medicinal Bath Granules (WGMG) has been developed that maintains the core therapeutic characteristics of the traditional decoction while enhancing clinical applicability and standardization. It is composed of five kinds of Tibetan medicinal plants in equal proportions, the formula includes Juniperus formosana Hayata (Branch and Leaf), Rhododendron anthopogonoides Maxim. (Flower), Myricaria germanica (L.) Desv. (Stem and Leaf), Ephedra saxatilis Royle ex Florin (Stem), and Artemisia sieversiana Ehrhart ex Willd. (Whole Plant).

This study aimed to identify the active constituents of WGMG as well as understand the pharmacological mechanisms of WGMG in the treatment of collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats. Furthermore, WGMG was screened for its core anti-inflammatory effects via the TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 signaling pathways.

UPLC-Q-TOF/MS was used to characterize chemical components of WGMG in rat serum and synovial fluid. Potential targets and the associated pathways were predicted using network pharmacology. CIA rats in vivo, were treated with WGMG via medicinal bath treatment at doses of 2.95, 5.90, and 11.8 g/L for 28 days. The effectiveness of the treatment was determined by looking at the arthritis scores, swelling measurements of the paws, and the serum cytokines that were measured by ELISA. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and Safranin O-fast green staining were used to examine histopathological alterations. The Western blot, immunohistochemistry, and RT-PCR analyzes were used to uncover the underlying molecular mechanisms targeting on TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 inflammasome-related signaling molecules.

The findings of the study revealed identification of a total of 89 compounds from WGMG, which were mainly composed of alkaloids, flavonoids, phenylpropanoids, phenolic acids and fatty acids. In addition, total of 28 and 21 compounds were respectively identified from serum and synovial fluid. Both serum and synovial fluid had eighteen common compounds such as kaempferol and trans-ferulic acid. The network pharmacology research indicates that 68 overlapping targets between WGMG components and RA were revealed. Moreover, TLR4/NF-κB was found to mediate the inflammation by regulating the signaling pathway. In CIA rats, WGMG-H group significantly decreased arthritis scores, paw swelling, and spleen index, indicating relievers of symptoms of arthritis. According to histopathological examination, WGMG-H reduced synovial hyperplasia, inflammatory cell infiltration, and cartilage erosion. Moreover, WGMG-H inhibited the serum levels of NF-κB, TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-18 while enhanced IL-4 levels. Mechanistically, the protein and mRNA expression of TLR4, NF-κB, NLRP3, ASC, and caspase-1 were downregulated by WGMG, with high-dose WGMG having therapeutic efficacy similar to dexamethasone.

WGMG shows potent anti-inflammatory activity via inhibitory effect on NLRP3 inflammasome activation, which due to inhibition of TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway. This pharmacological mechanism is likely attributed to the bioactive components kaempferol and trans-ferulic acid. This research shows how WGMG may work in the body. The authors hope their findings might lead to new treatments for rheumatoid arthritis.

title: A tissue-penetrably engineered deoxyribonuclease 1 to prevent nasal polyp formation in chronic rhinosinusitis.
abstract: The study focuses on neutrophilic chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS), a condition characterized by persistent inflammation and resistance to corticosteroid therapy. The research highlights the role of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in mucosal damage and polyp formation. A genetically engineered deoxyribonuclease 1, AR-CR8 Dnase1, was evaluated for its therapeutic potential in a mouse model of neutrophilic CRS. The study involved isolating human neutrophils and inducing NET formation using LPS, followed by the development of an animal model for CRS and polyps through intranasal administration of LPS and Staphylococcal toxin. AR-CR8 Dnase1 demonstrated efficacy in degrading NET-like structures in LPS-stimulated human neutrophils and significantly reduced nasal polyps in the mouse CRS model. Intranasal administration of AR-CR8 Dnase1 was as effective as dexamethasone injections in reducing polyp numbers and NET accumulation. The findings suggest that AR-CR8 Dnase1 could serve as an alternative therapeutic for CRS patients who are unsuitable for steroid therapy. However, further studies are required to assess dosing, durability, and safety before clinical application. The study does not involve human subjects, and no adverse events or specific drug effects are reported.

Further studies are recommended to evaluate its clinical applicability.
aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Neutrophilic chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is characterized by persistent inflammation and often responds poorly to corticosteroid therapy. In this disease, neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are increasingly recognized as key mediators of mucosal damage and polypogenesis. The removal of NETs by deoxyribonuclease 1 could be a potential therapeutic approach to overcome steroid resistance in neutrophilic CRS. In this study, we established a mouse model of neutrophilic CRS and evaluated the effect of a genetically engineered deoxyribonuclease 1 'AR-CR8 Dnase1' on NETs and polyp formation in the mice.

Human neutrophils were isolated and treated with LPS to induce NET formation. An animal model for neutrophilic CRS and polyps was developed by intranasal administration of LPS and Staphylococcal toxin. H&E staining and immunofluorescence were performed to identify polyps, NETs, and immune cells in nasal cavities.

AR-CR8 Dnase1 effectively degraded NET-like structures in LPS-stimulated human neutrophils. In the mouse CRS model, the intranasal administration of AR-CR8 Dnase1 noticeably reduced the burden of nasal polyps. The intranasal treatment of Dnase1 was effective as much as an injection of dexamethasone in reducing polyp number and NET accumulation in this model.

These results suggest that an engineered deoxyribonuclease 1 like AR-CR8 Dnase1 be an emerging bio-drug to inhibit inflammatory reaction and polyp formation in patients with neutrophilic CRS. AR-CR8 Dnase1 may be an alternative therapeutic for patients with CRS who are not suitable for steroid therapy, and further studies comparing dosing, durability, and safety are needed before considering clinical use.

Not applicable.

summary: The study focuses on neutrophilic chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS), a condition characterized by persistent inflammation and resistance to corticosteroid therapy. The research highlights the role of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in mucosal damage and polyp formation. A genetically engineered deoxyribonuclease 1, AR-CR8 Dnase1, was evaluated for its therapeutic potential in a mouse model of neutrophilic CRS. The study involved isolating human neutrophils and inducing NET formation using LPS, followed by the development of an animal model for CRS and polyps through intranasal administration of LPS and Staphylococcal toxin. AR-CR8 Dnase1 demonstrated efficacy in degrading NET-like structures in LPS-stimulated human neutrophils and significantly reduced nasal polyps in the mouse CRS model. Intranasal administration of AR-CR8 Dnase1 was as effective as dexamethasone injections in reducing polyp numbers and NET accumulation. The findings suggest that AR-CR8 Dnase1 could serve as an alternative therapeutic for CRS patients who are unsuitable for steroid therapy. However, further studies are required to assess dosing, durability, and safety before clinical application. The study does not involve human subjects, and no adverse events or specific drug effects are reported.
authorPerspective: The article suggests that AR-CR8 Dnase1 could be a promising alternative therapeutic for CRS patients resistant to steroid therapy, emphasizing its effectiveness in reducing polyp formation and NET accumulation in the mouse model. Further studies are recommended to evaluate its clinical applicability.

These test subjects were exposed to AR-CR8 Dnase1 and dexamethasone (the drug of study) for comparative evaluation.

However, the study does not specify any adverse events or other medical significance induced by dexamethasone.

In this study, dexamethasone was administered via injection to mice with neutrophilic CRS to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing nasal polyps and NET accumulation.

title: Endometrial Cell Senescence and Recurrent Spontaneous Abortion: Biomarker Potential of UCP2 and GSR.
abstract: The study explores the molecular mechanisms behind recurrent spontaneous abortion, focusing on endometrial cell senescence and its role in the pathology. It identifies uncoupling protein 2 (UCP2) and glutathione reductase (GSR) as significantly upregulated genes associated with cellular senescence. Increased activity of natural killer and T cells in affected tissues suggests an immune component in the condition. Drug prediction analysis highlights dexamethasone and menadione as potential treatments, indicating their therapeutic potential in improving endometrial health and reducing miscarriage risk. However, the study does not provide specific data on the administration of dexamethasone or its effects on human subjects. Further clinical studies are recommended to validate these findings and explore therapeutic applications. The study emphasizes the importance of oxidative stress-induced senescence in recurrent spontaneous abortion and identifies UCP2 and GSR as promising biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: This study explores the molecular mechanisms driving recurrent spontaneous abortion, a condition affecting 1-5% of women of reproductive age, with 40-50% of cases unexplained. Focusing on endometrial cell senescence, a process linked to irreversible cell cycle arrest, the research identifies uncoupling protein 2 (UCP2) and glutathione reductase (GSR) as key contributors to this pathology. By analyzing transcriptome data from the Gene Expression Omnibus database, 21 genes associated with cellular senescence were found to be differentially expressed, with UCP2 and GSR significantly upregulated. These findings were validated using a hydrogen peroxide-induced senescence model in human endometrial stromal cells. Diagnostic potential was confirmed through receiver operating characteristic curve analysis, showing promising results for both UCP2 and GSR. The study also observed increased activity of natural killer and T cells in affected tissues, pointing to an immune component in recurrent spontaneous abortion. Drug prediction analysis highlighted dexamethasone and menadione as potential treatments. These insights suggest that oxidative stress-induced senescence plays a critical role in recurrent spontaneous abortion, with UCP2 and GSR as promising biomarkers and therapeutic targets to improve endometrial health and reduce miscarriage risk. Further clinical studies are needed to validate these findings and explore their therapeutic applications.
aiInferenceData.Title: Endometrial Cell Senescence and Recurrent Spontaneous Abortion: Biomarker Potential of UCP2 and GSR.

In this study, Dexamethasone was highlighted as a potential treatment for recurrent spontaneous abortion, which is not listed among its conventional uses. This qualifies as off-label use.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study suggests Dexamethasone as a potential treatment for recurrent spontaneous abortion, which is an off-label use.

title: Therapy-induced PSMA2 Sensitizes Prostate Cancer Cells to Residual Androgen and Promotes Neuroendocrine Lineage Transformation.
abstract: The study investigates the role of PSMA2 in prostate cancer cells under androgen receptor (AR) blockade therapy, specifically focusing on the effects of Enzalutamide. It highlights that while Enzalutamide is initially effective in treating prostate cancer, it induces PSMA2 expression, which accelerates HSP90 turnover and hypersensitizes AR to residual androgen. This leads to AR nuclear activity even under androgen-poor conditions and confers resistance to Enzalutamide. Furthermore, PSMA2 promotes lineage plasticity, enhancing transcriptional and phenotypic conversion toward treatment-emergent neuroendocrine prostate cancer (tNEPC). The study identifies PSMA2 as a stress-induced node that maintains AR-dependent survival under androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and drives the neuroendocrine transition. The findings suggest that PSMA2 is a therapeutically actionable driver of tNEPC evolution, presenting an opportunity for rational interception of the lethal ADT-CRPC-tNEPC trajectory. However, specific details about human subjects, adverse events, or direct clinical outcomes are not provided due to the lack of access to the full article.
adverseEvent: Adverse events: The study mentions Enzalutamide resistance and neuroendocrine lineage transformation as adverse outcomes associated with PSMA2 induction.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Aberrant activation of the androgen receptor (AR) pathway drives prostate cancer (PCa). Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and next-generation AR blockade (e.g., enzalutamide) are initially effective, but virtually all patients develop castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), which frequently transitions to treatment-emergent neuroendocrine PCa (tNEPC) following AR suppression. The molecular logic that links AR blockade to lineage plasticity remains incompletely understood. Here, we identify PSMA2 (Proteasome Subunit Alpha 2) as a treatment-induced effector that mechanistically connects AR blockade to tNEPC evolution. Enzalutamide induces PSMA2 expression in AR-expressing PCa cells. Enforced PSMA2 expression accelerates HSP90 turnover, hypersensitizes AR to residual post-castration androgen, drives AR nuclear activity under androgen-poor conditions, and confers enzalutamide resistance. Conversely, PSMA2 silencing stabilizes HSP90, desensitizes CRPC to androgen, and re-sensitizes resistant cells to enzalutamide-induced cell death. Importantly, PSMA2 also promotes lineage plasticity: treatment-induced PSMA2 enhances transcriptional and phenotypic conversion toward tNEPC. Thus, we uncover a single stress-induced node (PSMA2) that both maintains AR-dependent survival under ADT and fuels the neuroendocrine transition. PSMA2 marks an AR-hypersensitized transitional state and is itself a therapeutically actionable driver of tNEPC evolution, revealing an opportunity for rational interception of the lethal ADT-CRPC-tNEPC trajectory.
aiInferenceData.Title: Therapy-induced PSMA2 Sensitizes Prostate Cancer Cells to Residual Androgen and Promotes Neuroendocrine Lineage Transformation.
aiInferenceData.Vancouver_citation: Patterson N, Badoi A, Vadla GP, Hasani M, Moyer J, De la Nuez Ramirez C, Chabu YC. Therapy-induced PSMA2 Sensitizes Prostate Cancer Cells to Residual Androgen and Promotes Neuroendocrine Lineage Transformation. bioRxiv. 2025;
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: The drug of study, Enzalutamide, is conventionally used for treating high-risk biochemical recurrent non-metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (nmHSPC), metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC), high-risk non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), and metastatic CRPC under specific conditions. In this study, Enzalutamide was used to investigate its effects on prostate cancer cells, particularly its role in inducing PSMA2 expression and promoting neuroendocrine lineage transformation. This qualifies as off-label use since the study focuses on molecular mechanisms and lineage plasticity rather than the conventional therapeutic applications listed.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links Enzalutamide to the induction of PSMA2 expression, which promotes neuroendocrine lineage transformation and enzalutamide resistance in prostate cancer cells.

title: Graded Notch Signaling Functions as a Rheostat of Lineage Plasticity and Therapy Resistance in Prostate Cancer.
abstract: The study investigates the molecular mechanisms underlying resistance to androgen receptor-targeted therapies, specifically enzalutamide, in castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). It identifies Notch signaling as a graded rheostat that governs cell fate transitions and lineage plasticity, which are critical factors in therapy resistance. The research highlights that intermediate Notch activity maintains a stem-like progenitor state, while reduced or elevated signaling drives differentiation toward luminal or neuroendocrine lineages. During CRPC progression and enzalutamide resistance, Notch signaling becomes dynamically rewired, peaking in progenitor-like populations that sustain plasticity and survival. The study utilized CRISPR-mediated knockout and pharmacologic inhibition of Notch signaling, which depleted these progenitor cells and restored enzalutamide sensitivity. This suggests that the level of Notch signaling, rather than its binary presence, dictates lineage directionality and therapeutic response in CRPC. The findings establish Notch signaling as a tunable and actionable driver of resistance, offering potential therapeutic strategies to overcome enzalutamide resistance in prostate cancer.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Resistance to androgen receptor (AR)-targeted therapies such as enzalutamide in castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) often arises through lineage plasticity, yet the molecular mechanisms that define this process remain incompletely understood. While previous studies reported that Notch1 and Notch2 exert distinct and sometimes opposing effects in prostate cancer differentiation, the integrated role of Notch pathway activity has not been systematically explored. Here, we identify Notch signaling as a graded Rheostat that governs prostate cancer cell fate transitions. Integrative transcriptomic and functional analyses revealed that intermediate Notch activity maintains a stem-like progenitor state, whereas reduced or elevated signaling drives divergent differentiation trajectories toward luminal or neuroendocrine lineages, respectively. During CRPC progression and enzalutamide resistance, Notch signaling becomes dynamically rewired, peaking in progenitor-like populations that sustain plasticity and survival. Both CRISPR-mediated knockout and pharmacologic inhibition of Notch signaling depleted these progenitor cells and restored enzalutamide sensitivity. These findings demonstrate that the level, rather than the binary presence, of Notch signaling dictates lineage directionality and therapeutic response in CRPC, establishing it as a tunable and actionable driver of resistance.

title: Cost-effectiveness analysis of eight first-line treatments for metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer in China.
abstract: The article focuses on a cost-effectiveness analysis of eight first-line treatments for metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) in China, including enzalutamide plus androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). The study utilized a partitioned survival model to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and economic impact of these treatments over a 10-year horizon. Enzalutamide plus ADT yielded the highest quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) at 4.55, indicating its clinical effectiveness. However, abiraterone plus ADT emerged as the most cost-effective strategy with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of US$17,437.16 per QALY, which is substantially below the willingness-to-pay (WTP) threshold set at three times China's GDP per capita. The study highlights the economic and clinical considerations for selecting first-line treatments for mHSPC but does not provide specific details on adverse events or patient outcomes related to enzalutamide or other drugs.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: The treatment of metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) has shifted from androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) alone to doublet or triplet regimens building on ADT. However, the cost-effectiveness analysis of first-line treatments for mHSPC in China is uncertain. This study aims to perform a 10-year horizon health economic evaluation to comparatively analyze the cost-effectiveness of eight treatment regimens for mHSPC from the perspective of China's healthcare system, including (1) ADT alone and ADT plus one of the following: (2) docetaxel, (3) abiraterone, (4) apalutamide, (5) enzalutamide, (6) rezvilutamide, (7) darolutamide and docetaxel, (8) abiraterone and docetaxel. Partitioned survival model was developed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of eight first-line treatment regimens for mHSPC. Drug costs were primarily extracted from pharmaceutical databases. The key outcomes were quality adjusted life years (QALYs), costs and the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER). Willingness-to-pay (WTP) threshold was set as three-time China's gross domestic product (GDP) per capita (US$38,024) per QALY. For costs, the 10-year cost estimates ranged from US$120,844 for ADT alone to US$216,294 for darolutamide plus ADT with docetaxel. For clinical effectiveness, enzalutamide plus ADT yielded the highest QALYs (4.55), while ADT alone gained lowest QALYs (3.01). For cost-effectiveness, the three treatment regimens of ADT alone, abiraterone plus ADT and enzalutamide plus ADT constituted the cost-effectiveness frontier. Abiraterone plus ADT emerged as the most cost-effective strategy, indicative of an ICER of US$17437.16 per QALY, substantially below WTP threshold. Abiraterone plus ADT was likely to be cost-effective for mHSPC treatment at a WTP threshold of three-time per capita GDP per QALY.

summary: The article focuses on a cost-effectiveness analysis of eight first-line treatments for metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) in China, including enzalutamide plus androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). The study utilized a partitioned survival model to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and economic impact of these treatments over a 10-year horizon. Enzalutamide plus ADT yielded the highest quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) at 4.55, indicating its clinical effectiveness. However, abiraterone plus ADT emerged as the most cost-effective strategy with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of US$17,437.16 per QALY, which is substantially below the willingness-to-pay (WTP) threshold set at three times China's GDP per capita. The study highlights the economic and clinical considerations for selecting first-line treatments for mHSPC but does not provide specific details on adverse events or patient outcomes related to enzalutamide or other drugs.
authorPerspective: The article comments on the cost-effectiveness and clinical effectiveness of enzalutamide plus ADT, noting that it yielded the highest QALYs among the eight treatment regimens analyzed. However, abiraterone plus ADT was identified as the most cost-effective strategy.

title: Impact of Metastatic Hormone-sensitive Prostate Cancer Treatments on Health-related Quality of Life: A Systematic Review and Network Meta-analysis.
abstract: The study systematically reviewed and analyzed the impact of various treatment strategies on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC). It compared androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) alone or combined with placebo, radiotherapy, abiraterone, apalutamide, enzalutamide, and/or docetaxel. The network meta-analysis evaluated 12-month treatment effects using standardized mean differences (SMDs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). ADT combined with abiraterone demonstrated significantly less pain, less fatigue, and better physical functioning compared to ADT combined with enzalutamide, apalutamide, or placebo. However, ADT combined with abiraterone was associated with worse general health perception compared to ADT alone, ADT combined with docetaxel, and ADT combined with radiotherapy. The study highlighted that HRQoL outcomes differ across treatment strategies, with ADT combined with abiraterone yielding the most favorable HRQoL profile at 12 months. The study also noted limitations, including heterogeneity and few eligible trials. While enzalutamide was mentioned, the study primarily emphasized the comparative benefits and drawbacks of abiraterone in HRQoL outcomes.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
In metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC), health-related quality of life (HRQoL) is key for personalised treatment decisions. We compared the impact of different mHSPC treatment strategies on HRQoL, tackling a previously unaddressed challenge in comparing the outcomes across different patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs).

A systematic review was conducted of prospective studies reporting HRQoL outcomes of androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) alone or with placebo, radiotherapy, abiraterone, apalutamide, enzalutamide, and/or docetaxel in mHSPC (CRD42021227902). Databases were searched in April 2022 and April 2024. HRQoL domains across different PROMs were harmonised using the Wilson and Cleary model. A frequentist network meta-analysis (NMA) compared 12-mo treatment effects using standardised mean differences (SMDs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). Statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05.

Of the 24 articles included, nine were analysed in the NMA (eight trials, n = 6248). ADT + abiraterone resulted in significantly less pain than ADT + placebo (SMD: -0.22, 95% CI [-0.33; -0.10], p < 0.001), ADT + apalutamide (SMD: -0.17, 95% CI [-0.31; -0.02], p = 0.022), and ADT + enzalutamide (SMD: -0.23, 95% CI [-0.37; -0.09], p = 0.001). Less fatigue was observed with ADT + abiraterone versus ADT + enzalutamide (SMD: -0.45, 95% CI [-0.88; -0.02], p = 0.041). ADT + abiraterone showed significantly better physical functioning than ADT + enzalutamide (p = 0.015) and ADT + placebo (p = 0.032). Both were also associated with significantly worse general health perception than ADT alone, ADT + docetaxel, and ADT + radiotherapy. General health perception and overall quality of life were significantly better with ADT + abiraterone than with ADT + enzalutamide, ADT + apalutamide, and ADT + placebo (p < 0.001). The limitations include heterogeneity (0-76%) and few eligible trials.

HRQoL outcomes differ across treatment strategies for mHSPC. At 12 mo, ADT + abiraterone yielded the most favourable HRQoL profile.
