title: 3D Bioprinted Human Synovium-Cartilage Models Mimic Rheumatoid Arthritis Microenvironment and Recapitulate In Vivo Therapeutic Responses.
abstract: The article discusses the development of a 3D bioprinted human synovium-cartilage model designed to mimic the microenvironment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and replicate in vivo therapeutic responses. This in vitro model incorporates chondrocytes recellularized type II collagen scaffold and a bi-layered Gelatin-Matrigel hydrogel containing fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLS), proinflammatory macrophages, and protective barrier macrophages. The model successfully recapitulates key inflammatory processes associated with RA, such as the production of proinflammatory mediators, degradative enzymes, reactive oxygen species generation, FLS invasion into cartilage, macrophage phenotypic alterations, and depletion of extracellular matrix components. The study validates the model's effectiveness in screening anti-arthritis drugs, specifically celecoxib and tofacitinib, and demonstrates its accuracy in replicating in vivo pathological conditions through transcriptomic and proteomic analysis. The model's response to drugs is compared to a rat model of RA, highlighting its potential as a reliable tool for preclinical drug screening in RA therapeutics. However, no specific data on human subjects or adverse events is provided, and the full article is not available for further details.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) models play crucial roles in therapeutic discovery and fundamental research. However, current models have limited success at accurately simulating in vivo microenvironment and lacking intricate cellular cross-talk. Here, this work presents a human in vitro RA model that faithfully captures functional and compositional properties of cartilage and synovial lining in vivo, established with chondrocytes recellularized type II collagen scaffold and 3D-bioprinted bi-layered Gelatin-Matrigel hydrogel incorporating fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLS) and proinflammatory macrophages in the top layer and protective barrier macrophages in the bottom layer. This synovium-cartilage system recapitulates key inflammatory processes akin to RA, including enhanced production of proinflammatory mediators and degradative enzymes, as well as reactive oxygen species generation, invasion of FLS into cartilage, phenotypic alterations of macrophages and the depletion of cartilaginous extracellular matrix components. The established model enables effective screening of anti-arthritis drugs, which is validated by leveraging celecoxib and tofacitinib. Furthermore, the transcriptomic and proteomic landscape of this model demonstrates accuracy in replicating in vivo pathological conditions. Notably, this in vitro model reflects the response of the disease to the drug compared to the rat model of RA. Overall, this study provides reliable in vitro human synovium-cartilage models for screening preclinical drugs in RA therapeutics.
aiInferenceData.Title: 3D Bioprinted Human Synovium-Cartilage Models Mimic Rheumatoid Arthritis Microenvironment and Recapitulate In Vivo Therapeutic Responses.

The study demonstrated that the model accurately reflected the therapeutic response of RA to Celecoxib, as well as to another drug, Tofacitinib. However, there is no mention of Celecoxib inducing any specific medical event or adverse event in the test subjects.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: Celecoxib is conventionally used as a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) to treat pain and inflammation associated with conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. It is typically administered orally. In this study, Celecoxib was used as part of the drug screening process to evaluate its therapeutic response in the 3D bioprinted human synovium-cartilage model, which mimics the RA microenvironment.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link Celecoxib to any negative or adverse effects within the test subjects. It focuses on validating the therapeutic response of the drug in the RA model without mentioning any side effects or adverse events.

title: The divergent roles of tryptophans W354 and W217 in OCT1 transport: similar localization, distinct functions.
abstract: The article investigates the roles of specific amino acids in the hepatic organic cation transporter 1 (OCT1), which is responsible for transporting various structurally diverse substrates, including drugs such as morphine, metformin, sumatriptan, and fenoterol. The study utilized cryo-EM data and functional analyses to explore the effects of mutations in amino acids W217, W354, and I446 on OCT1 transport in HEK293 cells. The W354A mutation resulted in a complete loss of function for all tested substrates, while the W354Y mutation retained partial OCT1 activity. Molecular dynamics simulations revealed that W354 stabilizes OCT1 in its outward open conformation by forming a hydrogen bond with N453. On the other hand, W217A showed substrate-dependent effects, with smaller and less lipophilic substrates being more strongly affected. The study also identified a compensatory mechanism between W217 and F244, as the double mutant W217A/F244A significantly reduced uptake of all tested substrates. I446 mutations had only marginal effects on OCT1 transport. The findings highlight the distinct roles of W354 and W217 in OCT1 function and substrate specificity, with W354 being crucial for conformational changes and W217 contributing to substrate interaction. While morphine is mentioned as one of the substrates transported by OCT1, the study does not provide specific data on its transport or adverse effects related to morphine.

aiInferenceData.Author_perspective: The article comments on the distinct roles of amino acids W354 and W217 in OCT1 transport and substrate specificity, emphasizing their importance in the function and interaction of OCT1 with various substrates. However, it does not provide specific opinions on the effect of morphine or other drugs on human subjects.
aiInferenceData.Abstract: Hepatic organic cation transporter 1 (OCT1, SLC22A1) has a broad spectrum of structurally diverse substrates, including drugs like morphine, metformin, sumatriptan, and fenoterol. Here, we leveraged existing cryo-EM data to identify amino acids that constrain the binding pocket toward the intracellular lumen and performed functional analyses to determine their roles in OCT1 transport, in general, and in substrate specificity, in particular. We mutated W217, W354, and I446 and analyzed their effects on the transport of 27 structurally highly diverse substrates in HEK293 cells. The W354A mutant resulted in a complete loss of function for all tested substrates, whereas only the W354Y mutant partially retained OCT1 activity. Molecular dynamics simulations and functional analyses suggest that W354 affects OCT1 transport by forming a hydrogen bond with N453 in transmembrane helix 10, thereby stabilizing OCT1 in its outward open conformation. W217A showed strongly substrate-dependent effects, with the aromatic ring of tryptophan being the key property affecting transport. Smaller, less lipophilic substrates were more strongly affected. The substrate-specific effects of the W217A mutant correlated significantly with those of the F244A mutant. The double mutant W217A/F244A strongly reduced uptake of all tested substrates, indicating a compensatory mechanism between these two amino acids. I446 showed only marginal effects on OCT1 transport. Our data suggest that W354 is crucial for OCT1 function by mediating the switch from an inward- occluded to inward-open conformation but is not directly involved in substrate interaction. In contrast, W217, along with the previously known F244, contributes to the substrate specificity of OCT1.

It is typically administered orally, intravenously, or via other routes depending on the clinical scenario. In this study, morphine was not administered to patients but was used as a substrate in functional analyses involving HEK293 cells to study OCT1 transport mechanisms.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study does not link the drug of study to any negative or adverse effects. It focuses on the transport properties of OCT1 and the role of specific amino acids in substrate specificity, including morphine.

title: Primates as animal models for CPP research.
abstract: The article discusses the use of nonhuman primates (NHPs) as models for conditioned place preference (CPP) research, a method used to evaluate the rewarding effects of drug and non-drug stimuli. The review highlights the neurophysiological differences between rodents and humans, emphasizing the limitations of rodent models and the ethical challenges of human research. Over the past 25 years, CPP protocols have been applied to NHPs, specifically macaques and marmosets, with 14 studies meeting the inclusion criteria. The findings demonstrate that CPP effects were consistently observed with cocaine, methylphenidate, and palatable food in marmosets, and with morphine and methamphetamine in macaques. The article suggests that NHPs offer greater translational validity compared to rodent models due to their closer neurobiological and behavioral similarities to humans. However, the article does not provide specific details about human subjects, drug administration, or adverse events, as the focus is on animal models.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Conditioned place preference (CPP) is a widely used method to assess the rewarding effects of drug and non-drug stimuli. This paradigm has been successfully demonstrated across several species, although rats seem to be the most prevalent model. Given the significant neurophysiological discrepancies between rodents and humans, as well as the technical and ethical limitations of research involving the latter, CPP protocols employing nonhuman primates (NHPs) have been reported in the past 25 years. In this review, we examined the literature on CPP studies using NHPs, including a variety of unconditioned stimuli. A total of 14 studies, involving macaques or marmosets, met the inclusion criteria. Overall, findings indicate that CPP effects were consistently achieved using cocaine, methylphenidate (MPH), and highly palatable food in marmosets, as well as with morphine and methamphetamine (METH) in macaques. Despite the relatively low number of reports, the available evidence suggests that NHP species represent viable and versatile alternatives for CPP research, offering greater translational validity compared to rodent models due to their closer neurobiological, cognitive, and behavioral similarities to humans.
aiInferenceData.Title: Primates as animal models for CPP research.

aiInferenceData.Justification: The drug of study was used in a non-conventional way to assess its rewarding effects in nonhuman primates.

title: Efficacy of Ultrasound-Guided PENG Block for Acute Pain Relief in Adult Hip Fracture Patients: A Double-Blind Randomized Trial.
abstract: The study evaluated the efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block for pain management in adult patients with hip fractures in an emergency department setting. Patients were randomized to receive either the PENG block with bupivacaine or a sham procedure, alongside standard intravenous analgesia. Pain scores were significantly lower in the PENG block group at multiple time intervals, and the requirement for rescue analgesia in morphine equivalents was also reduced. No significant adverse events were reported, including hematoma, quadriceps weakness, local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), or opioid-related adverse events. The study concluded that the PENG block is an effective and opioid-sparing analgesic strategy for acute hip fractures in the emergency department. Morphine was used as rescue analgesia, but no adverse effects were attributed to its use. The study highlights the potential of the PENG block to reduce opioid dependency and improve pain management outcomes in hip fracture patients.

Both groups were administered standard intravenous analgesia. The study aimed to evaluate pain relief over 3 hours and the need for rescue analgesia. No significant adverse events were reported during the study.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
We evaluated the efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block for initial pain management in adult emergency department (ED) patients with hip fractures.

This prospective, randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care academic ED. Adult patients (≥ 18 years) with traumatic hip fractures and Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) pain scores > 4 were randomized to ultrasound-guided PENG block with bupivacaine or sham procedure. Both groups received standard intravenous analgesia. The primary outcome was the difference in NRS scores over 3 h. Secondary outcomes included total rescue analgesia (morphine equivalents) and adverse events.

Of 167 screened, 80 patients were enrolled (40 per group). Pain scores were significantly lower in the PENG block group at 30 min (mean difference [MD] -3.2; 95% confidence interval [CI]-4.2 to -2.2), 60 min (MD -3.1; 95% CI -4.1 to -2.1), and 120 min (MD -2.0; 95% CI -2.6, -1.4), compared with sham. Total rescue analgesia was significantly lower in the PENG block group (MD -4.6 mg morphine equivalents; 95% CI -6.2 to -3.1). No significant adverse events were reported, such as hematoma, quadriceps weakness, signs of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), or significant opioid-related adverse events.

In adult ED patients with hip fractures, ultrasound-guided PENG block significantly reduced pain scores and opioid requirements compared with sham, with no significant adverse events reported. PENG block may be an effective, opioid-sparing analgesic strategy for acute hip fractures in the ED.

Clinical Trial Registry-India: CTRI/2023/08/056595.

It was used to manage pain in adult patients with hip fractures, which aligns with its conventional use for severe pain. Therefore, this does not qualify as off-label use.

title: Trace determination of morphine and codeine in whole blood samples using pH-switchable hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents based liquid phase microextraction followed by HPLC-UV.
abstract: The study focused on the development of an environmentally friendly and efficient method for the extraction and analysis of morphine and codeine in whole blood samples. Using pH-switchable hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents combined with HPLC-UV detection, the researchers synthesized seven solvents and investigated their pH-switchability. The method demonstrated high precision and accuracy, with relative standard deviation values for intra-day and inter-day measurements ranging from 3.7-4.3% and 5.4-6.2%, respectively. Calibration graphs were linear within the range of 1.5-300 μg L<sup>-1</sup>, and the limit of detection for both morphine and codeine was 0.5 μg L<sup>-1</sup>. The enrichment factor and extraction recovery for morphine and codeine were 152-166 and 76-83%, respectively. Morphine and codeine were successfully detected in the blood sample of an addicted person, and relative recoveries of spiked blood samples ranged from 91.8-107.0%. While the study highlights the effectiveness of the method in detecting these drugs, no specific adverse events, medical complications, or therapeutic effects related to morphine were discussed. The study does not provide detailed information about the human subject or any adverse effects associated with the drugs.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: An environmental friendly, fast, easy and inexpensive pH-switchable hydrophobic deep eutectic solvent-based liquid phase microextraction procedure was developed and combined with HPLC-UV detection for the extraction and analysis of morphine and codeine in whole blood samples. In this method, seven deep eutectic solvents were synthesized and then their switchability with pH was investigated. Deep eutectic solvents that could be switched with pH were used as extractant. Under the optimum conditions, relative standard deviation values for intra-day and inter-day of the method based on seven replicate measurements of 50 μg L<sup>-1</sup> of morphine and codeine in blood samples were in the range of 3.7-4.3% and 5.4-6.2%, respectively. The calibration graphs were linear in the range of 1.5-300 μg L<sup>-1</sup> and limit of detection for both analytes was 0.5 μg L<sup>-1</sup>. The enrichment factor and the extraction recovery of morphine and codeine were in the ranges of 152-166, and 76-83%, respectively. The results showed that both morphine and codeine were detected in the blood sample of the addicted person. The relative recoveries of real blood samples which have been spiked with different levels of morphine and codeine were 91.8-107.0%. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

title: Effect of antipsychotics on the focal adhesion pathway.
abstract: This study investigated the impact of antipsychotic drugs, including clozapine, on the focal adhesion pathway using NT2-N neuron-like cells. The research aimed to address the interaction between pharmacological treatments for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia and the expression of genes involved in the focal adhesion pathway. The study exposed NT2-N cells to amisulpride, aripiprazole, chlorpromazine, clozapine, haloperidol, olanzapine, quetiapine, risperidone, or a vehicle for 24 hours. Genome-wide mRNA expression analysis revealed that seven out of eight drugs, including clozapine, downregulated the expression of genes associated with the focal adhesion pathway. Focal adhesion was identified as the pathway with the most negative normalized enrichment score across all treatments. The findings suggest that focal adhesion pathways may play a role in the pathophysiology of bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. Furthermore, the study highlights the importance of distinguishing medication effects from disease mechanisms in psychiatric research, particularly given the medicated state of most study participants. While the study provides valuable insights into the molecular effects of antipsychotic drugs, it does not involve human subjects or report adverse events.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
Focal adhesions and their dynamic nature are essential for various physiological processes, including the formation of neurites, synaptic function and plasticity. Alterations in these processes have been associated with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

This study aimed to explore the impact of pharmacological treatments used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia on the expression of genes involved in the focal adhesion pathway, addressing a gap in understanding the interaction between medication effects and disease pathophysiology.

NT2-N (neuron-like) cells were exposed to treatment with amisulpride, aripiprazole, chlorpromazine, clozapine, haloperidol, olanzapine, quetiapine, risperidone, or vehicle for 24 h. Genome-wide mRNA expression was analysed using gene set enrichment analysis.

The analysis revealed that seven out of the eight drugs widely prescribed for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia downregulate the expression of genes associated with the focal adhesions pathway. Focal adhesion was the pathway with the most negative normalised enrichment score across all treatments.

Our results support the hypothesis that focal adhesion pathways may play a role in the pathophysiology of bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. Moreover, the data underscore the importance of differentiating medication effects from disease mechanisms in psychiatric research, a challenge compounded by the medicated state of most study participants.
aiInferenceData.Title: Effect of antipsychotics on the focal adhesion pathway.

aiInferenceData.Test_subject: NT2-N (neuron-like) cells were used as the test subject in this study. These cells were exposed to various antipsychotic drugs, including the drug of study, Clozapine, for 24 hours.
aiInferenceData.AOI_drug_effect: The drug of study, Clozapine, along with other antipsychotics, was found to downregulate the expression of genes associated with the focal adhesion pathway in NT2-N cells. This indicates that the drug had an effect on the test subject, specifically altering gene expression related to focal adhesions.
aiInferenceData.Approved_indication: The drug of study, Clozapine, is conventionally used as an antipsychotic medication primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. It is typically administered orally to patients with severe schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. In this study, Clozapine was administered to NT2-N cells in vitro to investigate its impact on gene expression related to the focal adhesion pathway, rather than to treat an illness.
aiInferenceData.Justification: The study links the drug of study, Clozapine, to a negative effect on gene expression in the focal adhesion pathway, which may have implications for understanding its impact on disease mechanisms in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

title: Sodium benzoate treatment linked to increased glutathione levels and improved positive and negative symptoms, global function, and quality of life in patients with clozapine-resistant schizophrenia: secondary analysis of a randomized clinical trial.
abstract: This study focused on the effects of sodium benzoate as an adjunctive treatment for patients with clozapine-resistant schizophrenia (CRS). The secondary analysis utilized data from a double-blind trial involving 60 patients randomized to receive either sodium benzoate (n=40) or placebo (n=20) for six weeks. Plasma levels of glutathione (GSH), a crucial antioxidant often reduced in schizophrenia, were measured at baseline and endpoint. The findings revealed that sodium benzoate treatment was associated with increased GSH levels compared to placebo. Furthermore, among the 40 patients receiving sodium benzoate, changes in GSH levels were correlated with improvements in positive and negative symptoms, quality of life, and global function. In contrast, no such correlations were observed among placebo recipients. The study highlights the potential of sodium benzoate to enhance GSH levels and improve clinical and functional outcomes in CRS patients. While clozapine was mentioned as part of the patient profile, the study primarily focused on the adjunctive effects of sodium benzoate. No adverse events or complications were reported in relation to the treatment, and the study calls for longer-term research in other populations to further validate these findings.

aiInferenceData.Abstract: Oxidative stress is implicated in schizophrenia. Glutathione (GSH), a crucial endogenous antioxidant, is usually reduced in individuals with schizophrenia. GSH and its precursor, N-acetyl cysteine, have demonstrated potential as adjunctive treatment for schizophrenia; however, their effectiveness appears inconsistent, possibly because of their limited ability to penetrate the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Administration of sodium benzoate, capable of crossing BBB, enhanced GSH capacity and antipsychotic-like activity in animals. Further, adjunctive benzoate therapy improved clinical and functional outcomes in patients with schizophrenia, including clozapine-resistant schizophrenia (CRS). Whether sodium benzoate can also boost GSH to exert its therapeutic efficacy for schizophrenia deserves elucidation. This secondary analysis used data from a double-blind trial, in which 60 patients with CRS were randomized to receive addon treatment of sodium benzoate (n = 40) or placebo (n = 20) for 6 weeks. Clinical and functional assessments were conducted bi-weekly. Plasma levels of GSH were assayed at baseline and endpoint. As a result, six-week treatment of sodium benzoate was linked to increased GSH levels than placebo. Among the 40 benzoate receivers, the changes in GSH levels were correlated with the improvements in positive symptoms, negative symptoms, quality of life, and global function. In comparison, among placebo recipients, GSH changes were not associated with any changes in clinical or functional variables. The findings suggest that benzoate treatment may be related with elevation in GSH levels in CRS patients and improvement in functional outcomes as well as positive and negative symptoms. Longer-term studies in other populations are necessary in the future.

title: Complete genome and comparative genomic analysis of cefpodoxime resistant Pantoea septica strain GABEPS69 isolated from saliva of a patient diagnosed with treatment resistant schizophrenia.
abstract: The study focuses on the complete genome sequencing and comparative genomic analysis of Pantoea septica strain GABEPS69, which was isolated from the saliva of a patient diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. The patient was prescribed clozapine, an antipsychotic medication, which led to a dysbiotic oral microbiome. The strain exhibited resistance to cefpodoxime, a third-generation cephalosporin, and harbored various virulence factors and antimicrobial resistance genes. The study highlights the presence of a conserved chromosomal class-A β-lactamase homologue and a plasmid containing an aerobactin pathogenicity island homologue, which is associated with enhanced virulence. Additionally, bioactive thiopeptide biosynthetic gene clusters were universally present in P. septica genomes, suggesting a role in microbiome modulation. The findings emphasize the clinical relevance of P. septica and the need for surveillance of transient oral microbiota in vulnerable populations, including patients receiving clozapine. However, specific details regarding the patient's clinical outcomes, adverse events, or drug effects were not provided in the abstract.

aiInferenceData.Abstract:
This study aims to generate the first complete genome of Pantoea septica and provide a thorough genomic characterisation of this under-documented species. The study seeks to enhance understanding of P. septica, clarifying features relevant to opportunistic infection in vulnerable cohorts.

P. septica GABEPS69 was an opportunistic coloniser isolated from the saliva of a patient prescribed the antipsychotic clozapine, leading to a dysbiotic oral microbiome. A hybrid sequencing approach yielded a closed genome comprising a 4.1 Mb chromosome and six plasmids. Phenotypic susceptibility was determined by disk-diffusion and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) assays. Its chromosomal and plasmidic content was bioinformatically analysed alongside all canonical GenBank available P. septica genomes and the type strains of taxonomic neighbours Pantoea piersonii and "Pantoea latae", with focus on virulence-factors (VFs), antimicrobial-resistance-genes (ARGs), metal-resistance-genes (MRGs) and biosynthetic gene clusters.

GABEPS69 exhibited a narrow resistance spectrum, displaying resistance to the third-generation cephalosporin cefpodoxime. Plasmid pGABEPS69_1 harboured an aerobactin pathogenicity island homologue; a locus implicated in enhanced virulence, that was also identified across most other P. septica genomes and in the closely related human-pathogen Pantoea piersonii. A conserved chromosomal class-A β-lactamase homologue was also identified. Additionally, a universal presence of bioactive thiopeptide biosynthetic-gene-clusters was observed in P. septica genomes, suggesting a potential role in microbiome modulation.

This study presents a first complete genome of P. septica, revealing its genomic architecture, resistance, and virulence potential. Detailed plasmid analysis and comparative genomics enhance our understanding of the species clinical relevance and microbiome-modulating capacity. These findings motivate surveillance of transient oral microbiota in at-risk populations, including patients receiving clozapine.
